'''ARTneo: the museum of Northeast Ohio art''', formerly the Cleveland Artists Foundation, was founded in 1984. It is a [[non-profit]] regional [[art history]] organization that explicitly exhibits and collects the works of [[Northeast Ohio]] artists. ARTneo also publishes research materials about these artists. Artists ARTneo exhibits include [[Carl Gaertner]], [[Jean and Paul Ulen]], [[Paul Travis]], [[Henry Keller]], [[Julian Stanczak]], [[Viktor Schreckengost]], [[Edris Eckhardt]] and hundreds others. The permanent collection contains over 3000 pieces of art.
== Focus == The work primarily consists of artists from the [[Cleveland School (arts community)|Cleveland School]] of artists, that is the artists who achieved success after attending the Cleveland School of the Arts, now called the [[Cleveland Institute of Art]].
== External links == *[http://artneo.org/ ARTneo] official website

{{ infobox theatre group | name = Amakhosi Theatre | image = | imagesize = | caption = | ArtisticDirector = [[Cont Mhlanga]] | formed = 1981 | location = [[Makokoba]] township, [[Bulawayo]], [[Zimbabwe]] | disbanded = | members = | notable = | homepage = | genre = [[Theatre]] }} '''Amakhosi Theatre Productions''' (also known as '''Amakhosi Academy of Performing Arts''') is a [[Zimbabwe]]an [[theatre company]] based at the Amakhosi Township Square Cultural Centre in [[Makokoba]] township, [[Bulawayo]]. The company was established under its current name in 1981 by [[Cont Mhlanga]],<ref>Dube, C. (1992). Amakhosi Theatre: Ako-Bulawayo. ''TDR'', 36 (2), p. 44</ref> and has since become an influential cultural institution in Zimbabwe, playing a role not only in stimulating the performance arts scene, but also in examining critical issues in politics, health, women's rights and development with urban and rural communities through a method of active audience engagement.<ref>Chinyowa, K. C. (2009). Emerging paradigms for applied drama and theatre practice in [[Africa]]n contexts. ''Research in Drama Education: The Journal of Applied Theatre and Performance'', 14 (3), 329 -346</ref>
==Origins and Development==
The group's origins go back to 1979 when Mhlanga and his Dragons Karate Club colleagues turned up one day for their training session at Makokoba's Stanley Hall and found the hall booked for a theatre workshop. The karate club members attended the workshop out of curiosity, and it was during this experience that their enthusiasm for theatre was first ignited.<ref>Dube, C. (1992). Amakhosi Theatre: Ako-Bulawayo. ''TDR'', 36 (2), p.44</ref> Cont Mhlanga began to attend theatre workshops in Bulawayo and Harare in 1980 and 1981 (in the newly independent Zimbabwe), from which he would return to share newly acquired skills with his karate club. In 1981, the Dragons Karate Club officially renamed itself “Amakhosi Productions”.<ref>Dube, C. (1992). Amakhosi Theatre: Ako-Bulawayo. ''TDR'', 36 (2), p.44</ref>
The performers became highly active in the township of Makokoba and beyond. By 1990 the group had performed 295 times on stage, and grown to 110 active members.<ref>Dube, C. (1992). Amakhosi Theatre: Ako-Bulawayo. ''TDR'', 36 (2), 44 – 47</ref> Initially Cont Mhlanga was the sole writer, director and producer of all the plays. However, later other Amakhosi playwrights, such as Cont's brother Styx Mhlanga, were to make contributions to the company’s extensive repertoire, while the company expanded and diversified.<ref>Visit to Amakhosi Township Square and interview with Styx Mhlanga, January 20th, 2011</ref>
==Historical and Cultural Context== Amakhosi was founded within a unique historical and cultural context. Prior to Zimbabwe’s 1980 attainment of political independence, [[Rhodesia]]n cultural and social life was polarised.<ref>Seda, O. S. (2004). Transculturalism in Post-independence Zimbabwean Drama: Projections of Zimbabwean Theatre at the Onset of a New Millenium. ''Zambezia'', 31 (2), p. 136</ref>
The Senior Drama Lecturer at the University of Zimbabwe, Owen Seda, notes that "as a conquest society, colonial Rhodesia was in dire need of legitimacy in its values and existence as a domineering settler society…Through theatre and other arts, western civilisation was contrasted with the lives of indigenous people who were regarded as uncivilised and without a culture."<ref>Seda, O. S. (2004). Transculturalism in Post-independence Zimbabwean Drama: Projections of Zimbabwean Theatre at the Onset of a New Millenium. ''Zambezia'', 31 (2), p. 136</ref>
It was inevitable that after independence this segregation of Zimbabwean theatre would continue. Indeed, for the first decade following Zimbabwe’s independence in 1980, the National Theatre Organisation (a colonial establishment) continued its support of exclusive white amateur theatre companies. In this context, Amakhosi emerged as a strand of revolutionary black nationalist theatre, critical not only of colonialism, but also of the post-independence leadership which it characterised as hypocritical and corrupt.<ref>Seda, O. S. (2004). Transculturalism in Post-independence Zimbabwean Drama: Projections of Zimbabwean Theatre at the Onset of a New Millenium. ''Zambezia'', 31 (2), p. 136-147</ref>
The [[Zimbabwe Association of Community based Theatres]] (ZATC), established six years after independence, promoted indigenous township theatre, with the aim of encouraging cultural equality. However, black and white theatre traditions remained confrontational throughout the 1980s. At the onset of the 1990s, the attempts by various cultural activists (such as [[Cont Mhlanga]]) to break racial divisions in the arts resulted in a "process of transculturalism and hybridity in post-independence Zimbabwean theatre; leading to production of plays that resonate with traditional forms of African theatre infused with elements of western drama…(producing) theatre works of outstanding cultural and artistic merit."<ref>Seda, O. S. (2004). Transculturalism in Post-independence Zimbabwean Drama: Projections of Zimbabwean Theatre at the Onset of a New Millenium. ''Zambezia'', 31 (2), p. 139</ref>
In the play ''Workshop Negative'' (see below) in 1986, Amakhosi showed its willingness from early on to collaborate across the divide (in this case with Chris Hurst, a white Zimbabwean actor from the exclusive white theatre tradition.)<ref>Seda, O. S. (2004). Transculturalism in Post-independence Zimbabwean Drama: Projections of Zimbabwean Theatre at the Onset of a New Millenium. ''Zambezia'', 31 (2), p. 141</ref>
==Amakhosi Productions== Cont Mhlanga has been described by theatre expert Jane Plastow as "a product of urban township life", in contrast to many other African [[playwright]]s who hail from the elite classes.<ref>Plastow, J. (1996). ''African Theatre and Politics: the evolution of theatre in Ethiopia, Tanzania and Zimbabwe – a comparative study''. Amsterdam: Rodopi, p. 175</ref>
Mhlanga's first plays – ''Children Children'' (1983), ''Book of Lies'' (1983) and ''Diamond Warriors'' (1983) – were performed in English, with little dialogue and extensive use of karate. Their themes were political – about colonisation, the theft of Africa’s cultural heritage and its natural wealth.<ref>Plastow, J. (1996). ''African Theatre and Politics: the evolution of theatre in Ethiopia, Tanzania and Zimbabwe – a comparative study''. Amsterdam: Rodopi, p. 175</ref><ref>Dube, C. (1992). Amakhosi Theatre: Ako-Bulawayo. ''TDR'', 36 (2), p. 44</ref> ''Ngizozula Lawe'' (1984) was the first play in isiNdebele, the local language of Matabeleland, and was consequently a breakthrough for Amakhosi. It involved elderly dancers from the [[Bulawayo Traditional Dancers' Association]], whose participation in the performance, according to Professor Caleb Dube, "legitimised Amakhosi’s existence".<ref>Dube, C. (1992). Amakhosi Theatre: Ako-Bulawayo. ''TDR'', 36 (2), p.45</ref>
The theatre group had an agenda, as Mhlanga recounts: "The intention was to make the group known in Makokoba, make it a local institution…We wanted what we did to be of significance to a local audience, and they should be able to recognise themselves in what we were doing. So the lines in the plays were to a large extent based on what I heard people saying and the way they talked, in the workplace, in bars and so on."<ref>Interview with Cont Mhlanga, Copenhagen, 8 September 1989, in Kaarsholm, P. (1990). Mental Colonisation of Catharsis? Theatre, Democracy and Cultural Struggle from Rhodesia to Zimbabwe. ''Journal of Southern African Studies'', 16 (2), p.270</ref>
Having captured the attention and admiration of the Makokoba people with ''Nansi Lendoda'' in 1985, which won five National Theatre Organization awards, the theatre group expanded beyond the township.<ref>Dube, C. (1992). Amakhosi Theatre: Ako-Bulawayo. ''TDR'', 36 (2), p. 45</ref>
From 1985 the actors began to engage their audiences in 'discussion theatre', often entering into controversial social, political and cultural topic areas.<ref>Kaarsholm, P. (1990). Mental Colonisation of Catharsis? Theatre, Democracy and Cultural Struggle from Rhodesia to Zimbabwe. ''Journal of Southern African Studies'', 16 (2), p.271</ref>
One such 'discussion theatre' performance – ''Workshop Negative'' (1986) – which the group had wanted to take on tour in [[Botswana]] and [[Zambia]], was cut short as it did not receive "the Government’s blessing",<ref>Kaarsholm, P. (1990). Mental Colonisation of Catharsis? Theatre, Democracy and Cultural Struggle from Rhodesia to Zimbabwe. ''Journal of Southern African Studies'', 16 (2), p.273</ref> due to its highly critical portrayal of the country’s leaders as hypocritical and corrupt. The controversial banning of the play, and the implications this had for other artists' freedom of expression, caused a deep sense of unease in the arts community. The Writers' Union saw the episode as a fundamental challenge to free speech,<ref>Kaarsholm, P. (1990). Mental Colonisation of Catharsis? Theatre, Democracy and Cultural Struggle from Rhodesia to Zimbabwe. ''Journal of Southern African Studies'', 16 (2), p.273</ref> and it was to signify just the beginning of Amakhosi’s many issues with oppressive authorities.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/may/12/david-smith-cont-mhlanga/ Smith, David. (2009) Interview with Cont Mhlanga (accessed 6. October 2011)]</ref>
''Citizen Mind'', produced in 1986, urged a revitalisation of Zimbabwean traditional cultures, arguing that they should be the basis for future development. ''Cry-Isilio'' (1987/88) dealt with the capitalist system and its perpetual repression of workers, as well as sexual harassment of under-privileged women.<ref>Chifunyise, S. (1990). Trends in Zimbabwean Theatre since 1980. ''Journal of Southern African Studies'', 16 (2), p.283</ref> "Stitsha" (1990) dealt with many serious issues of crime, unemployment, corruption, and the suppression of women. The play was taken on a European tour in 1990.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.aloismoyo.com/theatre.html/ |title=actor Alois Moyo (accessed 5. October 2011) |access-date=2011-10-08 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120425051812/http://www.aloismoyo.com/theatre.html |archive-date=2012-04-25 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
In 1990 the company branched out to radio with ''Ngokwako Sgadula'' (a popular serial about family planning), and TV with ''Tshada Laye'', a screen play about marriage and divorce (13 episodes).<ref>Dube, C. (1992). Amakhosi Theatre: Ako-Bulawayo. ''TDR'', 36 (2), 46</ref>
Many plays and European tours followed in the 1990s. Several Amakhosi dancers and actors, such as [[Alois Moyo]], have risen to prominence in the Zimbabwean theatre scene, or have headed abroad to advance their careers in [[South Africa]] and Europe. Zimbabwe's significant political and economic upheaval since 1999 has created serious setbacks for the theatre, both financially, and in the stifling of free expression. Cont Mhlanga has won several awards for his work, including the [[Freedom to Create Prize]] in 2008, for "practising protest theatre and challenging state ideologies in Zimbabwe for over 25 years. He has been the target of state surveillance, intimidation, harassment, arrest and detention."<ref>[https://archive.is/20120731041748/http://www.freedomtocreate.com/cont-mhlanga/ Freedom to create (accessed 7. October 2011)]</ref><ref>Visit to Amakhosi Township Square and interview with Styx Mhlanga, January 20th, 2011</ref>
==Social Change and Development Projects== Amakhosi Theatre has initiated several projects and collaborations with African and European organisations, and received vital funding support for its activities, mainly from [[Scandinavia]], through NGOs such as NORAD, [[DANIDA]] and [[HiVOS]].<ref>Seda, O. S. (2004). Transculturalism in Post-independence Zimbabwean Drama: Projections of Zimbabwean Theatre at the Onset of a New Millenium. ''Zambezia'', 31 (2), p.140</ref> Its main venue, the ''Amakhosi Township Square Cultural Centre'', with its offices, library, practice rooms, bar and open air stage, is a cultural hub hosting performances, concerts, dance and theatre workshops.<ref>Visit to Amakhosi Township Square and interview with Styx Mhlanga, January 20th, 2011</ref>
For much of the decade since the year 2000, Amakhosi Productions has lacked sufficient funding and revenue to support the level of activity that it was previously able to sustain. However, at a new alternative venue in 2011, in Bulawayo City centre - the '''Amakhosi Elite 400''' (already described as "Zimbabwe's premiere arts and culture hub") - the company has attempted to revive its activities and host a diverse array of performance events.<ref>http://[http://bulawayo24.com/index-id-entertainment-sc-events-byo-3634-article-Amakhosi+Elite+400+Zimbabwe's+premiere+arts+and+culture+hub.html/ Bulawayo 24News (accessed 7. October 2011)]</ref>
===Voices From Zimbabwe=== Voices From Zimbabwe began with a statement by Cont Mhlanga from the Amakhosi Theatre in 2007, announcing the launch of a movement to "support creative artists from all disciplines to produce, perform, distribute and amplify the voices of the majority who live in Difficult Times while exposing the trickery and hypocrisy of the minority who live in Good Times, while they claim to be acting on behalf of the people and the country, by taking such critical and sometimes protest works to the people by all means available and possible."<ref>[http://www.voicesfromzimbabwe.com/content/view/35/44// Voices from Zimbabwe (accessed 6. October 2011)]</ref>
===Amakhosi Theatre for Community Action (TCA)=== Established in 2001, this programme, uses a particular methodology created by the Amakhosi Theatre to "support and involve rural community members in the fight against HIV/AIDS" through the effective use of drama.<ref>[http://comminit.com/?q=africa/node/126245/ C-Capacity online resource center (accessed 7. October 2011)]</ref> It incorporates folk media like song, dance and narrative with spontaneous participation, to communicate the issue of the HIV/AIDS pandemic.<ref>Chinyowa, K. C. (2009). Emerging paradigms for applied drama and theatre practice in African contexts. Research in Drama Education: ''The Journal of Applied Theatre and Performance'', 14 (3), 335</ref> (In interviews Mhlanga emphasises that theatre is a part of people’s everyday activity, and in the African context it must diverge in some sense from the Western notion of theatre.)<ref>Mhlanga, C. (2002) Interview at Grand Palm Hotel, Gaborone, 26 November, in Chinyowa, K. C. (2007). Helping them to help themselves: case study of an integrated popular theatre approach in Africa. ''The Journal of Applied Theatre and Performance'', 12 (2), 140 (Mhlanga, interview 2002 in Chinyowa 2007: 140)</ref> The initial TCA practical theatre skills training programme lasted 1 year and taught the TCA methodology to 7 districts in Matabeleland province, which resulted in plays being performed to 80 000 people. The organizers stated that “community theatre can take the message to the people, instead of getting people to the theatre”. Amakhosi’s TCA development methodology is continuing to be implemented by Amakhosi in Zimbabwe, and other development groups elsewhere in Africa.<ref>Chinyowa, K. C. (2007). Helping them to help themselves: case study of an integrated popular theatre approach in Africa. ''The Journal of Applied Theatre and Performance'', 12 (2), 133-147</ref> The Theatre has received substantial funding from the Canadian International Development Agency (CIDA) for "addressing HIV/AIDS and Promoting Gender Equality through Music and Theatre."<ref>[http://www.acdi-cida.gc.ca/acdi-cida/contributions.nsf/Eng/2F5B1D5FDFEB08A285257290005928D6/ Canadian International Development Agency (accessed 6. October 2011)]</ref>
===Secondary School Drama=== Meanwhile, [[Styx Mhlanga]] continues to implement a new project in [[Matabeleland]], teaching secondary school literature texts to students by working with them on theatrical adaptations.<ref>Visit to Amakhosi Township Square and interview with Styx Mhlanga, January 20th, 2011</ref>

{{pp-vandalism|small=yes}} {{Infobox film | name = American Gangster | image = American Gangster poster.jpg |alt=A black-and-white picture, depicting Frank Lucas in a black suit and Richie Roberts in a white one. In front of them is the title American Gangster, with Russell Crowe and Denzel Washington's names above, and the film credits below. | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Ridley Scott]] | producer = {{Plainlist| *Ridley Scott * [[Brian Grazer]] }} | screenplay = [[Steven Zaillian]] | based on = {{based on|''The Return of Superfly''|Mark Jacobson}} | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Denzel Washington]] * [[Russell Crowe]] * [[Chiwetel Ejiofor]] * [[Cuba Gooding Jr.]] * [[Josh Brolin]] * [[Ted Levine]] * [[Armand Assante]] * [[John Ortiz]] * [[John Hawkes (actor)|John Hawkes]] * [[Rza|RZA]] <!--- Per poster billing block ---> }} | music = [[Marc Streitenfeld]] | cinematography = [[Harris Savides]] | editing = [[Pietro Scalia]] | studio = {{Plainlist| * [[Imagine Entertainment]] * [[Scott Free Productions]] * [[Relativity Media]] }} | distributor = [[Universal Studios|Universal Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|2007|10|19|[[Apollo Theater]]|2007|11|02|United States}} | runtime = 158 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = $100 million<ref name=bom/> | gross = $266.5 million<ref name=bom/> }} '''''American Gangster''''' is a 2007 American [[Biographical film|biographical]] [[crime film]] directed and produced by [[Ridley Scott]] and written by [[Steven Zaillian]]. The film is fictionally based on the criminal career of [[Frank Lucas (drug dealer)|Frank Lucas]], a gangster from [[La Grange, North Carolina]] who smuggled heroin into the United States on American service planes returning from the [[Vietnam War]], before being detained by a task force led by detective [[Richie Roberts]]. The film stars [[Denzel Washington]] and [[Russell Crowe]] in their first lead acting roles together since 1995's ''[[Virtuosity]]''. The film also co-stars [[Ted Levine]], [[John Ortiz]], [[Josh Brolin]], [[Chiwetel Ejiofor]], [[Norman Reedus]], [[Ruby Dee]], [[Lymari Nadal]] and [[Cuba Gooding Jr.]]
Development for the film initially began in 2000, when [[Universal Studios|Universal Pictures]] and [[Imagine Entertainment]] purchased the rights to a ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]'' magazine story about the rise and fall of Lucas. Two years later, screenwriter [[Steven Zaillian]] introduced a 170-page [[scriptment]] to Scott. Original production plans were to commence in [[Toronto]] for budget purposes; however, production eventually relocated permanently to New York City. Because of the film's rising budget Universal canceled production in 2004. After negotiations with [[Terry George]], it was later revived with Scott at the helm in March 2005. Principal photography commenced over a period of five months from July to December 2006; filming took place throughout [[New York City]] and concluded in [[Thailand]].
''American Gangster'' premiered in New York on October 20, 2007, and was released in the United States and Canada on November 2. The film was well received by most film critics, and grossed over US$266.5 million worldwide, with domestic grosses standing at $130.1 million. Many of the people portrayed, including Roberts and Lucas, have stated that the film took a lot of creative license with the story, and three former [[Drug Enforcement Administration|DEA]] agents sued Universal claiming the agency's portrayal was demoralizing. ''American Gangster'' was nominated for twenty-one awards, including two [[Academy Award]] nominations for [[Academy Award for Best Production Design|Best Art Direction]] and [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress|Best Supporting Actress]] (Ruby Dee), and won three including a [[14th Screen Actors Guild Awards|Screen Actors Guild Award]] for Outstanding Performance by a Female Actor in a Supporting Role for Dee.
==Plot== In 1968, [[Frank Lucas (drug dealer)|Frank Lucas]] is the right-hand man of [[Harlem]] gangster [[Bumpy Johnson|Ellsworth "Bumpy" Johnson]]. When Johnson dies of a heart attack, Lucas takes control of the Harlem crime scene.
After handing in almost $1 million that he found in a mobster's car, [[Newark, New Jersey|Newark]] detective [[Richie Roberts]] is ostracized in his precinct. After his exiled and addicted partner overdoses on a potent brand of [[heroin]] called "Blue Magic", Captain Lou Toback puts Roberts in charge of a task force that targets local suppliers. Lucas buys Blue Magic directly from producers in Thailand and smuggles it into the U.S. through returning [[Vietnam War]] servicemen. His low overhead allows him to eventually wholesale Blue Magic to most of the dealers in the New York area. With this monopoly, Lucas expands his control to nightclubs, casinos, and prostitution. He buys a mansion for his mother and recruits his five brothers, including Huey and Turner, as lieutenants to spread his empire. During his rise to becoming Harlem's crime boss, Lucas falls in love with Eva, a Puerto Rican beauty queen.
As Lucas' business prospers, he makes a point of operating quietly and dressing with a modest conservatism both as a sign of strength and to avoid attracting police attention. Also, he stays away from the drugs to avoid making hard decisions under the influence. However, Lucas violates these principles when he attends the [[Fight of the Century]] with Eva, sporting gaudy clothes that were a present by Eva; Roberts attends the fight, notices the previously unknown Lucas with even better seats than the Italian mobsters, and investigates him. Meanwhile, Lucas needs to deal with [[Lucchese crime family|Lucchese]] [[Italian-American Mafia|mafia]] boss Dominic Cattano, who threatens to destroy Lucas' family unless he gets in on a deal, and corrupt [[New York City Police Department|NYPD]] detectives led by Nick Trupo, who attempts to extort and blackmail him to give them a cut. Lucas must also compete with local crime figure [[Nicky Barnes]], a young gun trying to take over Harlem who has been diluting Lucas' Blue Magic and selling it under the same brand name. After the [[Fall of Saigon]] cuts off Lucas' supply, he is forced to rely on the other crime rings.
Roberts' detectives witness Frank Lucas' cousin and driver shoot a woman and then use the threat of a long sentence to get him to wear a [[Covert listening device|wire]]. The gathered information allows Roberts and his task force to identify and search one of the last planes carrying Lucas' stock, discovering Blue Magic in the coffins of dead returning servicemen. With this evidence they obtain a [[Warrant (law)|warrant]] to follow the drugs into Newark's projects and Lucas' heroin processing facility. In the ensuing shootout, Steve Lucas, Frank Lucas' young nephew who gave up a promising career for the New York Yankees to join Lucas' crime family, is killed. Meanwhile, Trupo, whose prized [[Shelby Mustang]] Lucas had destroyed, and his men break into Lucas' mansion to steal his emergency cash supply hidden under the doghouse, killing the dog. As Lucas gets ready to go after Trupo, his mother dissuades him from killing a cop, warning him that she and Eva will leave him if he does. Lucas is arrested after Roberts' team conducts a raid on the shops run by his brothers.
In the police station, Lucas offers to bribe Roberts, but is rebuffed. Instead, Roberts offers Lucas a chance at a shorter jail sentence if he aids his investigation of dirty cops in the NYPD and Lucas duly provides Roberts with the names. In the end, three quarters of the New York [[Drug Enforcement Administration|DEA]] are arrested and convicted, and a distraught Trupo commits suicide. Roberts, having just passed the bar exam, defends Lucas as his first client. Lucas is sentenced to 70 years in prison, of which he serves 15 years and is released in 1991.

Norman Reilly * Melissa Hill as Redtop * [[Clarence Williams III]] as [[Bumpy Johnson|Ellsworth "Bumpy" Johnson]] ''(uncredited)'' {{Div col end}}
==Production==
===Development and writing=== [[File:Russell Crowe TIFF 2006.jpg|left|thumb|upright|[[Russell Crowe]] (pictured here in 2006) worked with director Ridley Scott on the film's script.|alt=Russell Crowe in a premiere.]] In 2000, [[Universal Pictures]] and [[Imagine Entertainment]] purchased the rights to "The Return of Superfly", a ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]'' magazine story by [[Mark Jacobson]] about the rise and fall of the 1970s heroin kingpin Frank Lucas.<ref name="fame">{{Cite news | author=Kleinknecht, William | title=FROM FOES TO FRIENDS AND NOW ON TO FAME | work=[[The Star-Ledger]] | date=October 5, 2006 }}</ref> In 2002, screenwriter [[Steven Zaillian]] brought a 170-page script to director [[Ridley Scott]], who expressed interest in making two films from it. However, Scott did not immediately pursue the project, choosing to make ''[[Kingdom of Heaven (film)|Kingdom of Heaven]]'' instead. In November 2003, Universal and Imagine entered negotiations with [[Brian De Palma]] to direct ''Tru Blu'', with a script by Zaillian based on Frank Lucas.<ref name="re-imagined">{{Cite news | author=Fleming, Michael | url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117895211.html?categoryid=1236&cs=1 | title=U is re-Imagined | work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] | date=November 5, 2003 | accessdate=April 30, 2007 }}</ref><ref name=ew>{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20154184,00.html|title=Clash of the Titans|first=Josh|last=Rottenberg |date=October 25, 2007 |website=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|accessdate=November 12, 2012}}</ref> Zaillian interpreted the story as one of "American business and race", focusing the script thematically on corporate business.<ref>{{Cite news | author=Leland, John |authorlink=John Leland (journalist) | title=Gross National Product |work=The New York Times | date=October 29, 2006 }}</ref> Production was initially slated for a spring 2004 start.<ref name="re-imagined" /> In March 2004, the studio entered new negotiations with [[Antoine Fuqua]] to direct, as well as [[Denzel Washington]] to star in the film as Frank Lucas.<ref>{{Cite news | author=Snyder, Gabriel |author2=Michael Fleming | url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117901768.html?categoryid=1238&cs=1 | title='Tru Blu' has liftoff at Imagine | work=Variety | date=March 15, 2004 | accessdate=April 30, 2007 }}</ref> The following May, [[Benicio del Toro]] entered negotiations to star as Detective Richie Roberts, who brought down Lucas. Production of ''Tru Blu'' was reset to begin in early fall 2004, with the film slated for a release date of June 3, 2005.<ref>{{Cite news | author=Fleming, Michael | url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117905459.html?categoryid=1236&cs=1 | title=Del Toro's 'Tru' calling | work=Variety | date=May 23, 2004 | accessdate=April 30, 2007 }}</ref> In September 2004, [[Dania Ramírez|Dania Ramirez]] entered negotiations to join the cast of the film, now titled ''American Gangster''.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/news/topnews.php?id=6358 |title=Ramirez Joining Fuqua's American Gangster |publisher=ComingSoon.net |date=September 13, 2004 |accessdate=April 30, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930031431/http://www.comingsoon.net/news/topnews.php?id=6358 |archivedate=September 30, 2007 |df= }}</ref>
Universal Pictures reported that it greenlit ''American Gangster'' with a budget of $80 million, which escalated to $93 million, with $10 million for development costs and $3 million for the delay of the production start date. Sources close to the director insist that the budget was $93 million from the beginning. The studio also sought for ''American Gangster'' to be produced in Toronto rather than New York City to save money, but Fuqua resisted the re-location. The studio's parent company [[General Electric]] received [[tax credit]]s in New York City, so production was moved to the city. The move, however, inflated the budget to $98 million. Fuqua's camp insisted that it was seeking ways to reduce the budget, but the studio contended several aspects of the project under him. The director had wanted to film a Vietnam sequence in Thailand and to cast notable names such as [[Ray Liotta]] and [[John C. Reilly]] in minor roles. To add to the studio's budgetary concerns, Fuqua was rewriting the script during the preproduction process. The director also did not have a shot-list, final locations, and supporting actors signed to initiate production.<ref name=wrap>{{Cite news|author=Ascher-Walsh, Rebecca |author2=Jeff Jensen |url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,724273,00.html |title='Gangster' Wrap |work=Entertainment Weekly |date=October 22, 2004 |accessdate=November 3, 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071115130416/http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0%2C%2C724273%2C00.html |archivedate=November 15, 2007 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
Fuqua was fired on October 1, 2004, four weeks before principal photography would begin.<ref name=wrap /> The studio cited creative differences for the director's departure.<ref>{{Cite news | author=Fleming, Michael | url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117911326.html?categoryid=13&cs=1 | title=Fuqua ankles 'Gangster' | work=Variety | date=October 3, 2004 | accessdate=April 30, 2007 }}</ref> After Fuqua's departure, the studio met with [[Peter Berg]] to take over directing the film, and Denzel Washington had approved of the choice.<ref name=wrap /> Due to the search potentially escalating a budget already in the US$80 million range and the difficulty in recouping the amount based on the film's subject matter, Universal canceled production of ''American Gangster'', citing time constraints and creative elements for its reason.<ref>{{Cite news | author=Fleming, Michael | url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117911582.html?categoryid=13&cs=1 | title='American Gangster' pic rubbed out by U | work=Variety | date=October 6, 2004 | accessdate=April 30, 2007 }}</ref> The cancellation cost the studio $30 million, of which $20 million went to Washington and $5 million went to del Toro due to their [[Guarantee (filmmaking)|pay or play contract]]s.<ref name=wrap />
{{quote box|width=35%|align=right|quote="When I met Frank, I really understood what I saw as the arc of the character. He wears nice clothes and drives fancy cars and all that, so if that means glorifying it I guess that's the case. But for me I was looking at the arc of the character, and he don’t look that glorious right now."|source=—Denzel Washington discussing the arc of Frank Lucas<ref name=ny>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/10/29/movies/29lela.html|author=Rivetti Jr., Tony |title=Gross National Product: The Heroin Trade's New Face|website=[[The New York Times]]|publisher=[[The New York Times Company]]|date=October 29, 2006|accessdate=November 5, 2011}}</ref>}} In March 2005, ''American Gangster'' was revived as Universal and Imagine entered negotiations with [[Terry George]] to revise Zaillian's script and direct the film, which was to be financed with a target budget of US $50 million.<ref>{{Cite news | author=Fleming, Michael | url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117919334.html?categoryid=13&cs=1 | title=U's still high on 'Gangster' | work=Variety | date=March 13, 2005 | accessdate=April 30, 2007 }}</ref> [[Will Smith]] was approached to replace Washington as Frank Lucas, though an offer would be held off until George completed his revision of the script.<ref>{{Cite news | author=Fleming, Michael | url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117923659.html?categoryid=1238&cs=1 | title=Thesp's 'American' dream | work=Variety | date=May 30, 2005 | accessdate=April 30, 2007 }}</ref> George cut many key scenes, characters and Asian locations to reduce costs, but the project failed to progress given financial problems and Grazer feeling they "couldn't make it right" without the removed material.<ref name=latimes/><ref name=daily/>
After a meeting between Scott and Zaillian on another project, Zaillian brought the project up again with Scott, who decided he was ready to do it. Producer [[Brian Grazer]] and Imagine executive Jim Whitaker decided against pursuing George's attempt and to return to Zaillian's vision.<ref name="going">{{Cite news | author=Fleming, Michael | url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117940290.html?categoryid=1236&cs=1 | title=U gets going on 'Gangster' | work=Variety | date=March 23, 2006 | accessdate=April 30, 2007 }}</ref> In February 2006, [[Ridley Scott]] entered talks with the studio to take over ''American Gangster'' from George, returning to Zaillian's draft as the film's basis. Washington returned to his role as Lucas, and [[Russell Crowe]] was attached to star as Roberts.<ref name="redux">{{Cite news | author=Fleming, Michael | url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117938111.html?categoryid=10&cs=1 | title='Gangster' redux | work=Variety | date=February 13, 2006 | accessdate=April 30, 2007 }}</ref> Crowe was drawn to the project based on his previous work with the director on ''[[Gladiator (2000 film)|Gladiator]]'' and ''[[A Good Year]]'',<ref>{{Cite news | author=Morris, Wesley | url=http://www.boston.com/news/globe/living/articles/2006/11/05/russell_crowe_learns_to_smile/ | title=Russell Crowe learns to smile |work=[[The Boston Globe]] | date=November 5, 2006 }}</ref> while Washington wanted to work with Crowe again, after 1995's ''[[Virtuosity]]''.<ref name=ew/> Production was slated in summer 2006.<ref name="redux" />
Scott had discussed the script with Crowe as they worked on ''A Good Year'' in France, and they sought to take on the project. The director reviewed Zaillian's script, Terry George's rewrite, and a revision by [[Richard Price (writer)|Richard Price]] during the project's incarnation with director Antoine Fuqua. Scott preferred Zaillian's approach and chose to follow it. In realizing the project, the director encountered a challenge in the script since the characters Frank Lucas and Richie Roberts do not encounter each other until twenty minutes before the end of the film. The director sought to flesh out the private universes of the characters that would evolve and have scenes cut between the two characters to provide a balance. Elements like Frank Lucas's interaction with his family and Richie Roberts' dysfunctional marriage were written to add to the characters' backgrounds.<ref name=scott>{{Cite news | author=Douglas, Edward | url=http://www.comingsoon.net/news/movienews.php?id=38623 | title= Ridley Scott's ''American Gangster'' | publisher=ComingSoon.net | date=October 25, 2007 | accessdate=November 3, 2007 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20071027024412/http://www.comingsoon.net/news/movienews.php?id=38623| archivedate= October 27, 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The rappers [[T.I.]], [[Rza|RZA]] and [[Common (rapper)|Common]] were added to the cast to appeal to younger audiences.<ref name=jay />
[[File:Harlem condemned building.jpg|thumb|Many abandoned buildings in [[Harlem]] were shot, to give an accurate and authentic depiction of the area in the 1970s.|alt=An old-styled Harlem building.]] Scott chose to direct ''American Gangster'' based on the paradoxical values of Frank Lucas and Richie Roberts. The film somewhat focuses on the comparatively ethical business practices of the "wicked gangster" and the womanizing and failed marriage of the "do-gooder" police detective. Washington, who was not normally a fan of gangster films, chose to portray Lucas when he saw "the arc of the character" had ended with prices that Lucas paid for his actions.<ref name="fame" /> To prepare for their roles, the actors met their real-life counterparts. Washington acquired Lucas's Southern accent, and Crowe practiced to match Roberts's manner of speaking and body language, requesting tape recordings of Roberts to assist in his preparation.<ref name="fame" /> The following March, the studio rehired Zaillian to rewrite the script for ''American Gangster''.<ref name="going" /> It was rumored that Washington got paid another $20 million for when the project was greenlit again; that rumor proved to be false, as he signed on for his gross.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://weblogs.variety.com/thompsononhollywood/2007/10/american-gangst.html |title=American Gangster: A Grazer Tale |author=Thompson, Anne |work=Thompson on Hollywood |accessdate=November 4, 2007 |date=Oct 17, 2007 |quote=Denzel Washington had already gotten paid his upfront guarantee pay-or-play, so he signed on just for his gross. |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071107134457/http://weblogs.variety.com/thompsononhollywood/2007/10/american-gangst.html |archivedate=2007-11-07 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The budget had escalated to $100 million, which Grazer stated was unexpected given "It's not a [[high-concept]] comedy, it's not a fantasy movie, it's not a [[four-quadrant movie]]".<ref name=ew/> Grazer and Scott still had to pay back the studio $3 million for a [[cost overrun|budget overrun]].<ref name=latimes>{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2007/oct/15/business/fi-gangster15/|title='Gangster' gets a shot|date=October 15, 2007|first=Claudia|last=Eller|website=The Los Angeles Times|accessdate=November 16, 2012}}</ref>
===Filming=== [[Image:Bknavyard.JPG|thumb|left|Principal photography took place in several location throughout New York, including the [[Brooklyn Navy Yard]].|alt=Panoramic view of the Brooklyn Navy Yard.]] [[Principal photography]] began in July 2006 in [[New York City]].<ref name=daily>{{Cite web | author=Whipp, Glenn | url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/NOT+MAKING+IT+WOULD+BE+A+CRIME+'AMERICAN+GANGSTER'+OVERCOMES+MORE...-a0170398415| title=NOT MAKING IT WOULD BE A CRIME 'AMERICAN GANGSTER' OVERCOMES MORE OBSTACLES THAN MOST HOLLYWOOD DRAMAS| website=[[Los Angeles Daily News]]| date=October 28, 2007 | accessdate=November 5, 2011 }}</ref> ''American Gangster'' was filmed over a period of approximately four months in over 180 different locations, most of them across New York; it set the record for containing the highest number of filming locations of a movie.<ref name=scott /> Two months were spent in New York, with all the city's [[Borough (New York City)|five boroughs]] being used. Approximately fifty to sixty locations were set in Harlem alone. While in the neighbourhood, Scott stated that he found several interiors that had been untouched since the 1940s.<ref name=scott /> According to production designer Arthur Max, exhaustive [[location scouting]] was done to find parts of New York that could still resemble the city of the early 1970s, filming Lucas' headquarters at [[116th Street (Manhattan)|116th Street]] 20 blocks north, on 136th Street.<ref name=notes>{{Cite web|url=http://madeinatlantis.com/movies_central/2007/american_gangster_production_details.htm |title=''American Gangster'' Production Notes |website=Universal Pictures |accessdate=November 5, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131224113144/http://madeinatlantis.com/movies_central/2007/american_gangster_production_details.htm |archivedate=December 24, 2013 |df= }}</ref> In his interview with [[CraveOnline|ComingSoon.net]], Scott stated that "[he] just walked in [...] and [...] just sho[o]t in the house." Several [[gas mask]]s were brought by producers due to health hazards and sanitary concerns existing in the buildings. Scott found filming in Harlem to be difficult, commenting that the rapid [[gentrification]] in Harlem provided poor opportunities for shooting angles.<ref name=scott /> [[Hand-held camera]]s were extensively used to depict a "[[guerrilla filmmaking]]" style.<ref name=notes/>
Other locations for principal photography include the [[Brooklyn Navy Yard]], the [[Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum]], [[Old Westbury Gardens]], a segment of the [[George Washington Bridge]], and the [[New York Supreme Court, Appellate Division|Brooklyn Supreme Courthouse]]. [[Briarcliff Manor, New York|Briarcliff Manor]] in upstate [[New York (state)|New York]] had the locations for both the Lucas farm and the estate Lucas buys for his family.<ref name=notes/> Filming locations began setting up in [[Thailand]] in November 2006, after [[Branko Lustig]] consulted with Suvit Yodmanee, the country's tourism minister.<ref name=star>{{cite web|url=http://ecentral.my/news/story.asp?file=/2006/11/1/movies/15833311&sec=movies |title=Thailand beckons |website=[[The Star (Malaysia)|The Star]] |publisher=Star Publications |date=November 1, 2006 |accessdate=November 5, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120614040826/http://ecentral.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2006%2F11%2F1%2Fmovies%2F15833311&sec=movies |archivedate=June 14, 2012 |df= }}</ref> Filming for ''American Gangster'' concluded in [[Chiang Mai]] the following month.<ref name=star/>
Using his experience from visiting New York in the same time period in which the film's story took place, Scott sought to downplay a "[[The Beatles|Beatles]]" atmosphere to the film and to instead create a shabbier atmosphere, saying that "Harlem was really, really shabby, beautiful [[brownstone]]s falling apart."<ref name=scott /> Production and costume design was emphasized, transforming the location into the rundown streets of upper Manhattan from the late 1960s and early 1970s. Denzel Washington, as Frank Lucas, went through 64 different costume changes.<ref>{{Cite news | author=Schwartz, Robert | url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117963680.html?categoryid=1236&cs=1 | title='Gangster' puts hit on gentrification | work=Variety | date=April 24, 2007 | accessdate=April 30, 2007 }}</ref>
===Music=== In 2006, [[Greg Calloway]] was approached by producers to produce a soundtrack for the film. He presented the idea to [[Atlantic Records]] chairman [[Craig Kallman]], and one of the company's artists, [[T.I.]], got an acting role in the film. However, the deal did not go further because Universal Pictures owned the rights to the film; "It was a Universal film and they were not going to give the soundtrack to [[Warner Music Group|WMG]]" (Atlantic's parent company).<ref name="AG">{{cite web|url=http://gregcalloway.wordpress.com/bio/|title=Who Is Who is Greg Calloway?|publisher=Greg Calloway's official website|accessdate=November 11, 2012}}</ref> Thus Scott brought back [[Marc Streitenfeld]], who had worked with him in ''A Good Year''. The composer stated that "the overall tone needed to be something bigger and darker" given the characters' strong personalities, and while not being the original intention, he added shades of [[blues]] and [[soul music]] to fit the 1970s setting.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cinemablend.com/soundtracks/INTERVIEW-Marc-Streitenfeld-7411.html|publisher=Cinema Blend|title=INTERVIEW - Marc Streitenfeld|first=Scott|last=Gwin|date=November 21, 2007|accessdate=November 11, 2012}}</ref> The musical score for ''American Gangster'' was recorded between April and May 2007 by Streitenfeld, with the help of orchestrator Bruce Fowler and conductor Mike Nowak, using an 80-piece orchestra recorded in sections as well as acoustic pre-records, performed by Streitenfeld himself. Additional score material was composed and recorded by [[Hank Shocklee]].<ref>{{Cite news | author=Goldwasser, Dan | url=http://www.scoringsessions.com/news/87/ | title=Marc Streitenfeld scores Ridley Scott's ''American Gangster'' | publisher=ScoringSessions.com| date=May 15, 2007 | accessdate=May 20, 2007 }}</ref>
The official soundtrack album for ''American Gangster'' was released by [[Def Jam Recordings]] within a week of the film's release. In addition to Streitenfeld and Shocklee's score material, the soundtrack album also features songs influenced by music in the 1960s and 1970s, including from blues and soul musicians such as [[Bobby Womack]], [[The Staple Singers]], [[Sam & Dave]], and [[John Lee Hooker]].<ref name=jay>{{Cite news|author=Halbinger, David M. |author2=Leeds, Jeff |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/09/20/arts/music/20jayz.html |title=For Jay-Z, Inspiration Arrives in a Movie |work=The New York Times |date=September 20, 2007 |accessdate=November 3, 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120207172627/http://www.nytimes.com/2007/09/20/arts/music/20jayz.html |archivedate=February 7, 2012 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Grazer stated that "I wanted to introduce a visual and sonic world that is a contained entity of the '70s", and Scott felt it was vital to have "the brand of music that was Harlem at the time."<ref name=notes/>
Denzel Washington pressed Grazer into inviting rapper [[Jay-Z]] to write the film's score, but the producer "just didn't think there'd be enough for Jay-Z to do" given the intentions to do a soundtrack filled with 1970s music.<ref name=jay /> The film's trailer had already used Jay-Z's "Heart of the City (Ain't No Love)", and the rapper was invited to an advanced screening. The film had a profound resonance on the musician, who decided to create a concept album, also entitled ''[[American Gangster (album)|American Gangster]]''.<ref name=notes /> The rapper recorded tracks that were prompted by specific scenes in the film. It was speculated that the album's release in conjunction with the film would attract a young audience and help Universal Pictures generate profits to recover from the film's troubled development history.<ref name=jay /> According to Jay-Z: <blockquote> "It was like I was watching the film, and putting it on pause, and giving a back story to the story. It immediately clicked with me. Like ''Scarface'' or any one of those films, you take the good out of it, and you can see it as an inspiring film."<ref name=jay /> </blockquote>
==Release== [[File:Apollo Theater, Harlem (2009).jpg|upright|thumb|The premiere was at the [[Apollo Theater]] in [[Harlem]].|alt=Outside view of the Apollo film theater.]] ''American Gangster'' premiered in [[Harlem]] at the [[Apollo Theater]] on October 20, 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/american-gangster-premiere-gallery-1.108202|title='American Gangster' premiere|website=[[New York Daily News]]|publisher=Daily News|date=October 20, 2007|accessdate=November 5, 2011}}</ref> Over two weeks before the release of ''American Gangster'', a [[screener (promotional)|screener]] for the film leaked online.<ref>{{Cite news | author=| url=http://nymag.com/daily/entertainment/2007/10/american_gangster_leaked_onlin.html | title=‘American Gangster’ Leaked Online a Whole Week Early! | publisher=[[New York (magazine)|New York]] | date= October 24, 2007 | accessdate=October 24, 2007 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20071026083551/http://nymag.com/daily/entertainment/2007/10/american_gangster_leaked_onlin.html| archivedate= October 26, 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The film debuted in the United States and Canada on November 2, 2007 in 3,054 theaters.<ref>{{Cite news | author=McClintock, Pamela |author2=Dave McNary | url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117975237.html?categoryId=1082&cs=1 | title=Buzz builds for fall box office |work=Variety | date=November 1, 2007 | accessdate=November 2, 2007 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20071104073939/http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117975237.html?categoryid=1082&cs=1| archivedate= November 4, 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
===Box office===
In its opening weekend in the United States and Canada, it grossed an estimated $43.6 million, averaging $14,264 per theater, placing the film first in the weekend box office.<ref name=rueters>{{Cite news | url=http://in.reuters.com/article/2007/11/04/idINIndia-30327520071104 | title='American Gangster' squashes bees at box office|author=Goodman, Dean | publisher=[[Reuters]] | date=November 4, 2007 | accessdate=November 4, 2007 }}</ref> It marked the biggest opening weekend out of any film in both Washington and Crowe's careers.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=2414&p=.htm |title='American Gangster' No. 1 with a Bullet |accessdate=November 6, 2007 |author=Gray, Brandon |date=November 5, 2007 |publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]]| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20071116115255/http://www.boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=2414&p=.htm| archivedate= November 16, 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> In its second week, grosses declined by 44.8 percent to $24 million, being beaten out by ''[[Bee Movie]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url= http://www.boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=2416&p=.htm |title='Bee' Keeps Buzzing as 'Fred,' 'Lions' Don't Roar |accessdate=November 13, 2007 |author=Gray, Brandon |date=November 13, 2007 |publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]]}}</ref> In contrast by its third week, screenings for ''American Gangster'' increased to 3,110 theaters as the film surpassed the $100 million mark.<ref>{{Cite web|url= http://www.boxofficemojo.com/weekend/chart/?yr=2007&wknd=46&p=.htm|title=Weekend Box Office Results for November 16-18, 2007 |accessdate=November 19, 2007 |publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]]}}</ref> ''American Gangster'' finished its box office run in North America with $130,164,645.<ref name=bom/>
The film experienced similar success overseas. ''American Gangster'' was released in the United Kingdom on November 16, and became the highest-grossing film of the week, garnering £2.6 million ($5.3 million) in the box office.<ref name=guardian>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2007/nov/21/1|title=American Gangster guns down Beowulf in UK|website=[[The Guardian]]|publisher=Guardian News and Media|date=November 21, 2007|accessdate=November 5, 2011}}</ref> It repeated the feat in its second week, grossing an estimated £1.82 million ($3.7 million) at the box office and beating out ''[[Beowulf (2007 film)|Beowulf]]'' two consecutive times.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lovefilm.com/info/editorial.html?editorial_id=5363|title=American Gangster continues UK box office reign|website=[[LoveFilm]]|publisher=[[Amazon.com]]|date=November 27, 2007|accessdate=November 5, 2011}}</ref> The weekend of November 16–18 saw ''American Gangster'' take $14.7 million from fourteen territories internationally. At the same time, ''American Gangster'' expanded in the European market; it received $2.8 million from 366 theaters in Germany and $3.6 million from 366 screens in France during its opening weekend.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=2422&p=s.htm|title=Around the World Roundup: 'Beowulf' Leads Soft Lot|accessdate=November 5, 2011 |last=Bresnan|first=Conor|date=November 22, 2007 |publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]]}}</ref> Releases followed in Norway and Sweden the succeeding week, where it earned $392,608 and $465,238 from thirty-seven and fifty-nine theaters, respectively.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=2426&p=s.htm|title=Around the World Roundup: 'Beowulf' Tops Another Modest Weekend|accessdate=November 5, 2011 |last=Bresnan|first=Conor|date=November 29, 2007 |publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]]}}</ref> The film was released in the United Arab Emirates during the film's sixth week, and grossed a modest $281,922 at the box office during its first week in the emirate. Similarly, it earned $6.9 million in international markets during its sixth week, adding the total at the time to $40.9 million.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=2429&p=s.htm|title=Around the World Roundup: Softy 'Beowulf' Wins Another Weekend|accessdate=November 5, 2011 |last=Bresnan|first=Conor|date=December 6, 2007 |publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]]}}</ref>
By January 25, 2008, ''American Gangster'' opened in thirty-seven markets, bringing international grosses to $93 million.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=2447&p=s.htm|title=Around the World Roundup: 'Legend' First for Fifth Weekend|accessdate=November 5, 2011 |last=Bresnan|first=Conor|date=January 25, 2008|publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]]}}</ref> In February, screenings for the film debuted in Mexico—with a modest $820,482 opening weekend—and Japan, where it opened at the box office with $2.3 million, landing in second place.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=2451&p=s.htm|title=Around the World Roundup: 'Asterix' Leaps to the Top|accessdate=November 5, 2011 |last=Bresnan|first=Conor|date=February 10, 2008 |publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]]}}</ref> ''American Gangster'' grossed over $266.5 million worldwide at the box office, with international grosses making up 51 percent ($136.3 million). It ranked as the 19th highest-grossing film of 2007 both domestically and worldwide.<ref name=bom>{{Cite news | url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=americangangster.htm | title=American Gangster (2007) | publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]] | accessdate=April 25, 2009}}</ref>
===Home media=== ''American Gangster'' was released in DVD and [[HD DVD]] format on February 19, 2008. The home release included an unrated extended version of the film, featuring 18 additional minutes and an alternative ending.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2008/01/17/american-gangster-rolls-in|title=American Gangster Rolls In|first=David|last=McCutcheon|date=January 17, 2008|publisher=[[IGN]]|accessdate=November 12, 2012}}</ref> The film topped both the DVD sales charts with 4 million units during its first week in stores, more than three times as many copies as second place ''[[Michael Clayton (film)|Michael Clayton]]'', and the rental charts.<ref>{{cite web|title="Gangster" rides to top of DVD charts|first=Thomas K.|last=Arnold|website=[[Reuters]]|date=February 28, 2008|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2008/02/28/us-dvd-idUSN2849141620080228|accessdate=November 12, 2012}}</ref> ''American Gangster'' ended up as the 14th best-selling DVD of 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.the-numbers.com/dvd/charts/annual/2008.php|title=Top-Selling DVDs of 2008|publisher=The Numbers|accessdate=December 15, 2012}}</ref> It also topped the high-definition charts despite being released in the same week [[Toshiba]] announced it would discontinue the HD DVD format.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.highdefdigest.com/news/show/Disc_Sales/Universal/American_Gangster_HD_DVD_Tops_VideoScans_Weekly_High-Def_Disc_Sales_Chart/1526|title='American Gangster' HD DVD Tops VideoScan's Weekly High-Def Disc Sales Chart|date=February 29, 2008 |publisher=High-Def Digest|accessdate=November 12, 2012}}</ref> On October 14, the film saw its release on [[Blu-ray Disc|Blu-ray]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://film.thedigitalfix.com/content/id/68561/universal-gangster-titles-on-us-bd-in-october-artwork-added.html|date=September 5, 2008|first=Dave|last=Foster|title=Universal 'Gangster' titles on US BD in October - Artwork added |publisher=The Digital Fix|accessdate=November 12, 2012}}</ref>
A [[mobile game]] based on the film was released by [[Gameloft]] on November 1.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2007/11/16/american-gangster-review|title=American Gangster Review|first=George|last=Roush|date=November 16, 2007|publisher=IGN|accessdate=November 12, 2012}}</ref>
==Reception==
===Critical response=== Review aggregate [[Rotten Tomatoes]] reports that 80% of critics have given the film a positive review based on 212 reviews, with a rating average of 7/10, with the consensus being: "''American Gangster'' is a gritty and entertaining throwback to classic gangster films, with its lead performers firing on all cylinders."<ref name=tomatoes>{{Cite web | url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/american_gangster/ | title=American Gangster | publisher=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] | accessdate=November 12, 2007 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20071111030755/http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/american_gangster/| archivedate= November 11, 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> On [[Metacritic]], which assigns a [[Weighted arithmetic mean|weighted mean]] score out of 100 to reviews from film critics, the film has a score of 76 based on 38 reviews.<ref name=meta>{{Cite web | url=http://www.metacritic.com/film/titles/americangangster | title=American Gangster (2007): Reviews | publisher=[[Metacritic]] | accessdate=November 12, 2007 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20071111022132/http://www.metacritic.com/film/titles/americangangster| archivedate= November 11, 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
{{quote box|width=35%|align=left|quote="Like many moviemakers [...], Mr. Scott loves his bad guy too much. And by turning Lucas into a figure who seduces instead of repels, an object of directorial fetishism and a token of black resistance, however hollow, he encourages us to submit as well. Part of this is structural and economic: blood and nihilism are always better sells than misery and hopelessness. Yet there's also a historical dimension, because when Lucas strolls down a fast-emptying Harlem street after putting a bullet into another man’s head and the camera pulls back for the long view, you are transported into the realm of myth. Once, another gunman, or the director, might have taken direct aim at Lucas. But the world belongs to gangsters now, not cowboys."|source=—Manohla Dargis of ''The New York Times''<ref name=nyttimes>{{cite web|url=https://movies.nytimes.com/2007/11/02/movies/02gang.html|last=Dargis|first=Manolha|title=American Gangster (2007)|website=The New York Times|publisher=The New York Times Company|date=November 2, 2007|accessdate=November 5, 2011}}</ref>}} [[Roger Ebert]] of the ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'' gave the film a perfect four star rating and opined, "This is an engrossing story, told smoothly and well." Ebert also praised Crowe's performance, saying that his contribution to the storytelling was "enormous".<ref name=ebert>{{cite web |url=http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20071101/REVIEWS/711010303|title=American Gangster |accessdate=November 5, 2011 |date=November 2, 2007 |last=Ebert |first=Robert |website=[[Chicago Sun-Times]]}}</ref> Paul Byrnes of ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]'' felt that ''American Gangster'' was "one of the most intelligent gangster films in years" and expressed that the film offers "the spectacle of grand themes and two bigger-than-life characters played by two of the best actors in cinema." Concluding his review, Byrnes gave the film four out of four stars.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/news/film-reviews/american-gangster/2008/01/03/1198949939913.html|title=American Gangster|first=Paul|last=Byrnes|website=[[Sydney Morning Herald]]|publisher=[[Fairfax Media]]|date=January 3, 2008|accessdate=November 5, 2011}}</ref> [[IGN]]'s Jim "Stax" Vejvoda rated the film four out of five stars, praising the acting—particularly of the two protagonists, "both dynamic presences on-screen, with neither actor outweighing the other's importance to the story"—and declaring that despite being preceded by other gangster stories such as ''[[Scarface (1983 film)|Scarface]]'' and ''[[The Sopranos]]'', ''American Gangster'' managed to justify its existence with "emphasis on the human and class elements of the story".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ign.com/articles/2007/11/01/american-gangster-review-2|title=American Gangster Blu-ray Review|last=Monfette, Pirrello|first=Christopher, Phil|publisher=[[IGN]]|date=September 26, 2008|accessdate=November 5, 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071111092627/http://movies.ign.com/articles/831/831913p1.html|archivedate=November 11, 2007|deadurl=no}}</ref> Manohla Dargis of ''The New York Times'' strongly commended the film, opining that "greatness hovers just outside ''American Gangster''." She continued: "It's a seductive package, crammed with all the on-screen and off-screen talent that big-studio money can buy, and filled with old soul and remixed funk that evoke the city back in the day, when heroin turned poor streets white and sometimes red."<ref name=nyttimes/> These sentiments were echoed by Sukhdev Sandhu of ''[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]'', who asserted that the storyline was "amazing".<ref name="Tele">{{cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/film/filmreviews/3669300/Film-reviews-American-Gangster-and-Brick-Lane.html|title=Film reviews: American Gangster and Brick Lane|first=Sukhdev |last=Sandhu |website=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]] |publisher=Telegraph Media Group |date=November 16, 2007 |accessdate=November 5, 2011}}</ref>
In comparison, some reviewers were more critical of ''American Gangster''. Jonathan Crocker of ''[[Time Out (company)|Time Out London]]'' was polarized with the film, criticizing its aesthetics. In his review, he wrote, "Scott's meticulous aesthetics can’t touch the urban texture and deep focus of ''[[The French Connection (film)|The French Connection]]'', ''[[The Godfather]]'', ''[[Serpico]]'' and ''[[Prince of the City]]'' – all looming heavily in intertextual nods." In contrast, Crocker praised Washington's acting, writing, "He's immense: centering every scene with tractor-beam charisma, that dangerous, easy charm hovering between a luxury smile or blazing violence." In conclusion, Crocker gave the film three out of five stars.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.timeout.com/film/reviews/84261/american-gangster.html|title=American Gangster (2007)|last=Crocker|first=Jonathan|website=[[Time Out (company)|Time Out London]]|date=November 18, 2007|accessdate=November 5, 2011}}</ref> Similarly, Owen Gleiberman of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' gave the film a 'C-' grade, expressing that ''American Gangster'' is "never dull, but it could have used more good old-fashioned melodramatic intrigue." Gleiberman found Washington's performance to have "a ghastly ingenuity".<ref name=ewew>{{cite web |url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20155724,00.html|title=American Gangster (2007)|first=Owen |last=Gleiberman |website=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |date=October 31, 2007|accessdate=November 5, 2011}}</ref> ''[[Empire (film magazine)|Empire]]''{{'}}s Ian Freer rated the film three stars out of five; he stated that it was "undeniably enjoyable" and praised the cast, but also noted that he felt that "very little in the movie feels fresh, re-treading scenes, riffs and imagery from the whole history of crime flicks" and that the film did not explore enough of Lucas' story and Scott's visual imagination.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.empireonline.com/reviews/reviewcomplete.asp?FID=134550|title=American Gangster|website=Empire|first=Ian|last=Freer |accessdate=December 31, 2012}}</ref> [[Slant Magazine]] journalist Nick Schager harshly criticized the film, giving the film a one out of four stars. Schager remarked that the film was "dumb as a rock", and that it was "far too convinced of its import to be any fun."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slantmagazine.com/film/review/american-gangster/3211|title=American Gangster|first=Nick|last=Schager|website=[[Slant Magazine]]|publisher=|date=October 21, 2007|accessdate=November 5, 2011}}</ref> Giving ''American Gangster'' a two out of five stars, [[Peter Bradshaw]] of ''[[The Guardian]]'' was disappointed with Washington's acting, asserting, "He doesn't seem to relax and enjoy himself in the role, or even inhabit it very satisfyingly." He resumed: "He never has the menace of his dirty cop in ''[[Training Day]]'', and we don't see anything like the transformation from street-hustler to leader in ''[[Malcolm X (1992 film)|Malcolm X]]''. That shoulder-shimmying swagger is rarely seen, and the brand-classic robes of ''American Gangster'' sit on him heavily."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2007/nov/16/russellcrowe.denzelwashington|title=American Gangster |first=Peter |last=Bradshaw |website=[[The Guardian]] |publisher=Guardian News and Media |date=November 15, 2007 |accessdate=November 5, 2011}}</ref>
====Accuracy of the film==== In an interview with [[MSNBC]], Lucas expressed his excitement about the film and amazement at Denzel Washington's portrayal.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://insidedateline.nbcnews.com/_news/2007/10/26/4374157-breakfast-with-the-real-american-gangster |title=Breakfast with the real 'American Gangster'|publisher=[[MSNBC]]|date= October 26, 2007 |author=Davis, Bradley |work=[[Dateline NBC|Inside Dateline]]}}</ref> However, Lucas admitted to several news outlets that only a small portion of the film was true,<ref name=GangLiesNYPost>{{Cite web|title=GANGING UP ON MOVIE'S 'LIES' |website=New York Post |url=http://www.nypost.com/p/news/national/item_KbkhlJoI4y3vbAa9lEAEZN;jsessionid=3AB880C9B783B42F3625F06ACCFC358D |author=[[Susannah Cahalan]] |date=November 4, 2007 |accessdate=October 7, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100214041142/http://www.nypost.com/p/news/national/item_KbkhlJoI4y3vbAa9lEAEZN |archivedate=February 14, 2010 |df= }}</ref> and that much of it was fabricated for dramatic effect.<ref name=TheVoice>{{cite web|date = 2007-12-09|url = http://archive.voice-online.co.uk/content.php?show=12509|archive-url = https://archive.is/20120917180100/http://archive.voice-online.co.uk/content.php?show=12509|dead-url = yes|archive-date = 2012-09-17|title = The Real American Gangster|publisher = voice-online|accessdate = 2008-03-08|last = Janelle Oswald|quote = She spent five years in prison for aiding her husband's narcotic smuggling trade. Having to get used to the public life again after living like a 'ghost' since her release, the making of her partner's life on the big screen has brought back many memories, some good and some bad.}}</ref> In addition, [[Richie Roberts]] criticized the film for portraying him in a custody battle while in real life he never had a child. Roberts criticized the portrayal of Lucas, describing it as "almost noble".<ref name=GangLiesNYPost/>
[[Sterling Johnson Jr.]], a federal judge who served as a special narcotics prosecutor for the [[United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York]] and assisted the arrest and trial of Lucas, described the film as "one percent reality and ninety-nine percent Hollywood." In addition, Johnson described the real life Lucas as "illiterate, vicious, violent, and everything Denzel Washington was not."<ref>{{Cite news|author=Coyle, Jake|url=https://www.thestar.com/article/295102|title=Fabrications dim American Gangster's Oscar hopes|publisher=[[Toronto Star]]|date=January 17, 2008|accessdate=November 12, 2012}}</ref> Former [[Drug Enforcement Administration|DEA]] agents Jack Toal, Gregory Korniloff, and Louis Diaz filed a lawsuit against Universal saying that the events in the film were fictionalized and that the film [[Defamation|defamed]] them and hundreds of other agents.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.wpri.com/Global/story.asp?S=7734178&nav=F8nI|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080208093858/http://www.wpri.com/Global/story.asp?S=7734178&nav=F8nI|archivedate=February 8, 2008|title=DEA agents sue over 'American Gangster' |publisher=[[WPRI-TV|WPRI]]}}</ref> The lawsuit was eventually dismissed by US District Judge Colleen McMahon. While McMahon noted that the [[intertitle]] that appears at the end of the film, stating that Lucas' collaboration led to the arrest of many corrupt DEA agents, was "wholly inaccurate", in that Lucas' cooperation did not lead to the convictions, and admonished that "It would behoove a major corporation like Universal (which is owned by a major news organization, NBC) not to put inaccurate statements at the end of popular films", she stated that the film failed to meet legal standards of defamation because it failed to "show a single person who is identifiable as a DEA agent".<ref name="ABC/Reuters">{{Cite news|publisher =[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]]/[[Reuters]]|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2008-02-18/american-gangster-lawsuit-dismissed/1045622|title=American Gangster lawsuit dismissed|date= February 18, 2008}}</ref>
Many of Lucas' other claims, as presented in the film, have also been called into question, such as being the right-hand man of [[Bumpy Johnson]], rising above the power of the Mafia and [[Leroy Barnes|Nicky Barnes]], and that he was the mastermind behind the [[Golden Triangle (Southeast Asia)|Golden Triangle]] heroin connection of the 1970s. Ron Chepesiuk, a biographer of Frank Lucas, deemed the story as a myth. [[Associated Press]] entertainment writer Frank Coyle noted that "this mess happened partly because journalists have been relying on secondary sources removed from the actual events."<ref>Chepesiuk, Ron (January 17, 2008). [http://www.thenewcriminologist.com/article.asp?nid=2019 "New Criminologist Special - Frank Lucas, 'American Gangster,' and the Truth Behind the Asian Connection"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130822185808/http://www.thenewcriminologist.com/article.asp?nid=2019 |date=August 22, 2013 }}.</ref>
===Accolades=== ''American Gangster'' earned various awards and nominations, in categories ranging from recognition of the film itself to its screenplay and music, to the performances of [[Ruby Dee]] and [[Denzel Washington]]. Prior to the film's release, it was observed as a candidate for the [[Academy Award]]s based on its style and the performances of its actors, including the possibility of an [[Academy Award for Best Director]] for [[Ridley Scott]].<ref>{{Cite news|author=Harris, Paul |url=http://observer.guardian.co.uk/world/story/0,,2180318,00.html |title=Why drug lord fascinates US |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=September 30, 2007 |accessdate=November 3, 2007 |publisher= |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071106105939/http://observer.guardian.co.uk/world/story/0%2C%2C2180318%2C00.html |archivedate=November 6, 2007 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> It received two Academy Award nominations—Ruby Dee was nominated for [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress|Best Supporting Actress]], and Arthur Max and Beth A. Rubino (set decoration) were up for [[Academy Award for Best Production Design|Best Art Direction]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.oscars.org/awards/academyawards/oscarlegacy/2000-present/2008/winners.html |title=Nominees & Winners of the 80th Academy Awards |publisher=[[Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences]] |accessdate=November 6, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131012045551/http://www.oscars.org/awards/academyawards/oscarlegacy/2000-present/2008/winners.html |archivedate=October 12, 2013 |df= }}</ref> At the [[14th Screen Actors Guild Awards]], the film received two nominations, of which Dee won the award for [[Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Female Actor in a Supporting Role|Outstanding Performance by a Female Actor in a Supporting Role]], and the cast's overall performances earned the nomination for [[Screen Actors Guild Award for Outstanding Performance by a Cast in a Motion Picture|Outstanding Performance by a Cast]].<ref name="nomsentweekly">{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20167372,00.html |title=The 14th Annual SAG Award Nominations |accessdate=2007-12-20 |last=Bruno |first=Mike |date=2007-12-20 |publisher=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080103181246/http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0%2C%2C20167372%2C00.html?xid=rss-yahoogadget-todayslatest-20071220-SAG+nominations+go+%27Wild%27 |archivedate=January 3, 2008 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref><ref name="sagawardsnominations">{{cite web |url= http://www.sagawards.org/awards/nominees-and-recipients/14th-annual-screen-actors-guild-awards|title=The 14th Annual Screen Actors Guild Awards|publisher=[[Screen Actors Guild]]|accessdate=November 6, 2011}}</ref> At the [[Satellite Awards 2007|12th Satellite Awards]], [[Pietro Scalia]] attained an award for [[Satellite Award for Best Editing|Best Editing]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pressacademy.com/satawards/awards2007.shtml|title=2007 12th Annual Satellite Awards|publisher=[[International Press Academy]]|accessdate=November 6, 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071204081358/http://www.pressacademy.com/satawards/awards2007.shtml|archivedate=December 4, 2007}}</ref>
''American Gangster'' was nominated for three [[Golden Globe Award]]s, including a nomination for [[Golden Globe Award for Best Motion Picture – Drama|Best Motion Picture – Drama]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.goldenglobes.org/browse/?param=/year/2007 |title=65th Golden Globe Awards Nominations & Winners |accessdate=November 6, 2011 |publisher=[[Hollywood Foreign Press Association]] |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130415010453/http://www.goldenglobes.org/browse/?param=/year/2007 |archive-date=2013-04-15 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> At the [[61st British Academy Film Awards]], the film was nominated for five awards, but ultimately lost out.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bafta.org/awards-database.html?year=2007&category=Film&award=false|title=Film Nominations 2007|publisher=[[British Academy of Film and Television Arts]]|accessdate=November 6, 2011}}</ref> The film was up for four [[Satellite Awards 2007|Satellite Awards]], winning Best Editing.<ref>{{cite web |title=2007 12th Annual SATELLITE Awards |url=http://www.pressacademy.com/award_cat/2007/ |website=[[International Press Academy]] |accessdate=2008-12-21}}</ref> ''American Gangster'' was awarded [[Empire Award for Best Thriller|Best Thriller]] at the [[13th Empire Awards]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.empireonline.com/awards2008/winners/thriller.asp |title=Best Thriller |website=[[Empire (film magazine)|Empireonline.com]] |publisher=[[Bauer Consumer Media]] |year=2008 |accessdate=October 16, 2011 }}</ref> and recognized as a candidate for best film by the [[National Association for the Advancement of Colored People]] and the [[Broadcast Film Critics Association]].<ref name=bbc>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/7176289.stm |title=Coens land Critics' Choice Awards |accessdate=November 6, 2011 |date=January 1, 2008 |publisher=[[BBC News]]}}</ref> In addition, the film was included on 54 reviewer lists of the ten best films of 2007, three of them at the top spot.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://criticstop10.com/best-of-2007/|title=Best of 2007 - CriticsTop10|publisher=CriticsTop10|accessdate=2012-12-17}}</ref> Among the lists ranking ''American Gangster'' as one of the best of the year were those of ''[[The Miami Herald]]'',<ref name=mc07>{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/film/awards/2007/toptens.shtml |title=Metacritic: 2007 Film Critic Top Ten Lists |accessdate=February 25, 2008 |publisher=[[Metacritic]]|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080809211457/http://www.metacritic.com/film/awards/2007/toptens.shtml|archivedate = August 9, 2008}}</ref> ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' and the [[Associated Press]].<ref>{{Cite web| author=[[Peter Travers|Travers, Peters]] |date=December 19, 2007 |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/news/story/17686508/peter_travers_best_and_worst_movies_of_2007/6 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080619055506/http://www.rollingstone.com/news/story/17686508/peter_travers_best_and_worst_movies_of_2007/6 |archivedate=June 19, 2008 |title=Peter Travers' Best and Worst Movies of 2007 |website=[[Rolling Stone]] |accessdate= December 20, 2007}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.columbiatribune.com/2007/Dec/20071227Go!013.asp |archive-url=https://archive.is/20080103000750/http://www.columbiatribune.com/2007/Dec/20071227Go!013.asp |dead-url=yes |archive-date=January 3, 2008 |title='No Country for Old Men' earns nod from AP critics |accessdate=December 31, 2007 |author=Germain, David |author2=Lemire, Christy |date=December 27, 2007 |publisher=Associated Press, via [[Columbia Daily Tribune]] |df= }}</ref>
