{{Infobox writer <!-- for more information see [[:Template:Infobox writer/doc]] --> | name = Anne Haverty | image = | imagesize = | caption = | pseudonym = | birth_date = {{Birth year and age|1959}} | birth_place = [[Holycross]], [[County Tipperary]], Ireland | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = [[Novelist]], [[journalist]], [[Poet]] | nationality = [[Irish people|Irish]] | period = | genre = | subject = | movement = | education = [[Trinity College Dublin]], [[University of Paris|The Sorbonne]] | influenced = | signature = | website = {{URL|http://annehaverty.weebly.com}} }} '''Anne Haverty''' (born 1959) is an Irish novelist and poet.<ref name=ark>[http://www.litark.am/en/participant/anne-haverty Literary Ark :: Participants :: ANNE HAVERTY] Retrieved 2016-03-11.</ref> Haverty was educated at Trinity College Dublin and the Sorbonne and in 1992 won a scholarship to the European Film School at Ebeltoft in Denmark. Among Haverty's novels, ''[[One Day as a Tiger]]'' won the [[Rooney Prize for Irish Literature]] in 1997.<ref>[http://www.irelandliterature.com/author-database/author-holder/show/243 Ireland Literature Exchange (ILE) | Anne Haverty] Retrieved 2016-03-10.</ref>
==Biography== Anne Haverty was born in [[Holycross]], [[County Tipperary]] in 1959.<ref>[http://www.irishtimes.com/news/it-s-a-write-on-crowd-1.1098882 "It's a write-on crowd", ''The Irish Times'', Saturday, 2 September 2000, by Catherine Foley]</ref> Haverty was short-listed for the [[Costa Book Awards|Whitbread (Costa)]]. ''The Far Side of a Kiss'' was long-listed for the [[Man Booker Prize|Booker]]. A poetry collection, ''The Beauty Of The Moon'', was a Poetry Book Society Recommendation.
Haverty's biography ''Constance Markievicz: An Independent Life'' was first published in 1989 and re-issued in a revised edition as ''Constance Markievicz: Irish Revolutionary'' in 2016.
She co-directed (with Frank Stapleton) the documentary ''The Whole World In His Hands'', which won a special award at the Celtic Film Festival, and has written film and radio scripts including an adaptation of ''The Real Charlotte''. Haverty is a frequent contributor to ''[[The Irish Times]]'' and has written for many publications including the ''[[Times Literary Supplement|TLS]]'', the ''[[Daily Telegraph]]'' and the ''[[Sunday Independent (Ireland)|Sunday Independent]]''. Her work has appeared in several anthologies and has been translated into languages including German, Spanish, Portuguese and Armenian. She has read and lectured widely in Ireland and internationally. She was a member of the Literature Express (2000), was Visiting Professor at the Adam Mickievicz University in Poznan in 2005 and Writer In Residence at Trinity College Dublin (2007).
Haverty was educated at [[Trinity College Dublin]] and [[University of Paris|The Sorbonne]],<ref name=aosdana>[http://aosdana.artscouncil.ie/Members/Literature/Haverty.aspx?Cnuas=1 Anne Haverty - Current Member | Aosdana] Retrieved 2016-03-10.</ref> winning an under-21 short story competition at [[Listowel#Listowel Writers' Week|Listowel Writers Week]].<ref>[http://www.munsterlit.ie/Writer%20pages/Haverty,%20Anne.html Munster Literature Centre] Retrieved 2016-03-10.</ref> In 1992 she got a scholarship to the [[European Film College]] in [[Ebeltoft]], Denmark.<ref name=ark/>
A member of [[Aosdána]],<ref name=aosdana/> she was married to fellow author [[Anthony Cronin]],<ref>[http://www.rte.ie/radio1/miriam-meets/programmes/2010/1003/347862-031010/ Miriam O Callaghan meets writers Anthony Cronin and Anne Haverty] Retrieved 2016-03-11.</ref> and lives in [[Dublin]].<ref>[http://www.ricorso.net/rx/az-data/authors/h/Haverty_A/life.htm www.ricorso.net] Retrieved 2016-03-11.</ref>
===Non-fiction=== *''An Independent Life'' a biography of Constance Markievicz (1989 & 2016) <ref>https://www.lilliputpress.ie/product/constance-markievicz</ref> *''Elegant Times: A Dublin Story'' (1995) the story of [[Brown Thomas]] and [[Switzers (department store)|Switzers]] department stores.<ref>[http://www.fantasticfiction.co.uk/h/anne-haverty/elegant-times.htm www.fantasticfiction.co.uk] Retrieved 2016-03-11.</ref>
===Novels=== *''[[One Day as a Tiger]]'' (1997) *''The Far Side of a Kiss'' (2000) *''The Free and Easy'' (2006)
===Translations=== *''Ein Tag Als Tiger'' (2002)<ref>https://www.amazon.com/Ein-Tag-Tiger-Anne-Haverty/dp/3596146046/ref=sr_1_10?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1470861899&sr=1-10</ref> *''Tigre por un día'' (1998)<ref>https://www.amazon.es/Tigre-por-d%C3%ADa-Modernos-Clásicos/dp/8476693133</ref>
===Poetry collections=== *''The Beauty of the Moon'' (1999) *''A Break In The Journey'' (2018)

{{Refimprove|date=June 2016}} {{distinguish|Art director}} An '''artistic director''' is the executive of an arts organization, particularly in a theatre or dance company, who handles the organization's artistic direction.<ref>{{Cite book|title = An Actor Prepares|last = Stanislavski|first = Constantin|publisher = Theatre Arts Inc. New York|year = 1936|isbn = |location = |pages = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title = Meyerhold the Director|last = Rudnitsky|first = Konstantin, Transl. G. Petrov|publisher = Ardis, Ann Arbor, MI|year = 1981|isbn = |location = |pages = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title = The Empty Space|last = Brook|first = Peter|publisher = Harmondsworth, UK: Pelican|year = 1972|isbn = |location = |pages = }}</ref> They are generally a [[Theatrical producer|producer]] and [[Theatre director|director]], but not in the sense of a [[Business magnate|mogul]], since the organization is generally a [[Nonprofit organization|non-profit]] organization. The artistic director of a [[Theatre|theatre company]] is the individual with the overarching artistic control of the theatre's production choices, directorial choices, and overall artistic vision. In smaller theatres, the artistic director may be the founder of the theatre and the primary director of its plays. In larger non-profit theatres (often known in [[Canada]] and the [[United States]] as [[Regional theater in the United States|regional theatres]]), the artistic director may be appointed by the [[board of directors]].
==Overview== The artistic director of a performing arts company is similar to the [[Music director|musical director]] of an orchestra, the primary person responsible for planning a company's season. The artistic director's responsibilities can include (but are not limited to) choosing the [[Play (theatre)|material]] staged in a season, the hiring of creative/production personnel (such as [[theatre director|directors]]), and other theatre management tasks. He or she may also [[Theatre director|direct]] productions for the company. Artistic directors work closely with the general manager of the theatre, and contribute the artistic evaluation of projects and productions to be included in promotional, funding, and press materials. An artistic director also functions as a resource for the directors who are working to mount productions at the theatre and can provide support, counsel, and/or artistic input where requested.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Communication in Theatre Directing and Performance from rehearsal to production|last = Lanipekun|first = Jennifer|publisher = Cambria Press, New York|year = 2011|isbn = |location = |pages = Appendix I: Interview with Director 1, Artistic Director of Opera Company 1}}</ref> The artistic director is usually prepared to assume the production should the director become unable to complete his/her duties. Artistic directors are frequently regarded as the artistic representatives of theatre companies and are often required to speak about their theatre to the press. In the United States, artistic directors often have [[fundraising]] responsibilities as well.
In some ensemble companies, the artistic director is responsible for recruiting performers to act as a talent pool for the company's productions. This ensemble may include actors and artists of various disciplines. The artistic director functions as leader of this group, with the aim to create and/or realize various new and established works.
In [[ballet]], the artistic director is the head of a [[ballet company]]. They have overall responsibility for training the dancers as well as selecting and mounting productions. They are almost always a retired dancer. Often they also [[Choreography|choreograph]] some of the company's productions.
In some companies, the artistic director may also manage the day-to-day operations of the company, but in many (particularly larger) companies, the artistic director is often exempt from routine administrative duties, freeing him or her to concentrate on the art. In those cases, decisions about administration, business issues, finances, fundraising, board relations, donor relations, publicity, and marketing devolve to the responsibility of the general manager, chief operating officer, managing director, etc. or are discussed collaboratively.

revision.text: '''Brooke (Wetzel) Ciardelli''' is an American theater and film director, producer and writer. She founded the award-winning regional theater company [[Northern Stage]] in [[White River Junction]], [[Vermont]]. ==Early life and education== Brooke (Wetzel) Ciardelli was born in [[Manhattan]], [[New York (state)|New York]]. Her father, Joseph A. Wetzel (1934 - ), founded Joseph A. Wetzel Associates, a museum design firm and is currently a photographer...{{Cite news|title=Constance M. Nevil Weds Joseph Wetzel|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/27/style/constance-m-neville-weds-joseph-wetzel.html|newspaper=The New York Times|accessdate=21 December 2013|date=1984-05-27}} Her mother, Joyce E. Dickson (1934-2001), was a corporate art curator for the collections of Terence J. Fox, Greenwich, CT.{{cite web|last=Daniels|first=Mary|title=An Auction In Honor Of Tea|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1990-09-16/news/9003180084_1_tea-drinking-auction-block-caddies|work=Chicago Tribune|accessdate=21 December 2013}} After a competitive figure skating career, Ciardelli received her Bachelor of Arts degree from Sarah Lawrence College, with a concentration in theater.{{cite web|url=http://www.slc.edu/news-events/archived/2009-2010/2010-02-18-ciardelli.html|title=News and Events|work=Sarah Lawrence College News and Events|accessdate=21 December 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120410170707/http://www.slc.edu/news-events/archived/2009-2010/2010-02-18-ciardelli.html#|archive-date=2012-04-10|dead-url=yes|df=}} She subsequently worked at The Williamstown Theater Festival and the Broadway general managers/producers office of Gatchell & Neufeld. == Early Career: Film Production == In the 1990s, Ciardelli served as Co-Producer for ''A Stranger In The Kingdom'' starring [[Martin Sheen]] ; Producer for ''[[The Junior Defenders]]'', starring [[Ally Sheedy]];{{cite news|last=Harrison|first=Margot|title=Lights, Camera . . . Action?|url=http://www.7dvt.com/2007/lights-camera-action|accessdate=22 December 2013|newspaper=Seven Days|date=Aug 28, 2007}} and Co-Writer and Creative Producer for ''Wedding Band (My X-Girlfriend’s Wedding Reception'',{{cite news|last=Green|first=Susan|title=Director Martin Guigui Reels Out his Wish List|url=http://www.7dvt.com/2007/director-martin-guigui-reels-out-his-wish-list|accessdate=22 December 2013|newspaper=Seven Days|date=17 January 2007}} starring [[Mo Gaffney]] and [[Debbie Gibson]]. She served as a Producer of Special Projects for Burlington City Arts and worked for a number of years with the Burlington Jazz Festival and the Ben & Jerry’s Festival, as well as providing management services to a number of bands and singer/songwriters, including [[Jon Fishman’s]] side project Spastic, the Martin G uigui Band, the Chad Hollister Band, and others.{{cite web|title=Setlists Featuring Jon Fishman|url=http://phish.net/sideshows/jon-fishman/1995.html|accessdate=22 December 2013}} == Founding of Northern Stage == Ciardelli founded the Northern Stage Theater Company{{cite news|last=Finer|first=Jonathan|title=Town Sees Its Revival In Art|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A59382-2005Jan8.html|accessdate=22 December 2013|newspaper=Washington Post|date=January 9, 2005}} (Washington Post, Jonathan Finer), a non-profit, regional theater, in Burlington, VT in 1994. In 1997, Ciardelli moved the company to the historic Briggs Opera House in White River Junction (as reported in the Vermont Standard and the Vermont Times). Ciardelli led the company as Artistic Director and CEO from 1997-2012, during which time Northern Stage produced 111 main stage productions over 16 seasons, 52 directed or co-directed 52 by Ciardelli. (Boston Herald, Terry Byrne.),{{cite web|title=Northern Stage Bids Farewell to Artistic Director Brooke Ciardelli|url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/vermont/article/Northern-Stage-Bids-Farewell-to-Artistic-Director-Brooke-Ciardelli-20121117#|work=Broadway World|accessdate=22 December 2013}} and won five Moss Hart Awards for Excellence in Theater from the New England Theatre Conference.{{cite web|title=Moss Hart Award|url=http://www.netconline.org/moss-hart-award.php|accessdate=22 December 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131126081357/http://netconline.org/moss-hart-award.php#|archive-date=2013-11-26|dead-url=yes|df=}} Ciardelli also won an Addison Award for ''The Shrew Tamer'',{{cite web|last=Rossi|first=Carl A.|title=Addison Awards|url=http://www.theatermirror.com/CRyear4.htm|work=Theater Mirror|accessdate=22 December 2013}} which she adapted and directed, and an Owl Award for Best Artistic Director.{{cite web|title=The Complete Hoot|url=http://www.thecompletehoot.com/index.html|accessdate=12 December 2011}} As well as play readings, Ciardelli held enrichment activities in conjunction with some of the productions, and collaborated with other organizations, including [[Opera North (U.S.A.)]], [[Dartmouth College]]’s [[Hood Museum of Art]] and The AVA Gallery). Ciardelli also established the “Celebrity Saturday” talk-back series to allow audiences to interact directly with professional actors and directors, as well as the Athena Sunday series of expert pre-show lectures.{{cite web|title=Script Club: ''Damascus''|url=http://blip.tv/northern-stage-presents/script-club-damascus-4780133|work=Blip TV|accessdate=22 December 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131112032039/http://blip.tv/northern-stage-presents/script-club-damascus-4780133#|archive-date=2013-11-12|dead-url=yes|df=}} Ciardelli developed a series of educational programs, supported by various charitable and educational foundations, for fifth and sixth graders in Vermont and New Hampshire, including acting, singing, dancing, filmmaking and playwriting workshops led by working theater professionals from New York and around the country. The young performers and playwrights could see their work performed by professional actors, directors and designers on the Briggs Opera House stage.{{cite news|title=Project Playwright Turns Students Into Published Playwrights|url=http://www.jacneed.com/Archives/Archives_2008/040308Northern.htm|accessdate=22 December 2013|newspaper=New England Entertainment Digest|date=3 April 2008}} Ciarelli also arranged matinee productions of the company's professional productions for students.{{cite news|title=Northern Stage Ensemble Brings Beloved Children's Books to Life|url=http://www.ourherald.com/news/2008-06-12/Arts/a03.html|accessdate=23 December 2013|newspaper=Herald of Randolph|date=12 June 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303230908/http://www.ourherald.com/news/2008-06-12/Arts/a03.html|archive-date=2016-03-03|dead-url=yes|df=}}{{cite web|title=Tales of a Fourth Grade Nothing|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xLUepf3p1hw|work=Reel North Media|accessdate=23 December 2013}} In 2011, Ciardelli developed and implemented a National Endowment for the Arts literacy program, with events available live, over the Internet and via community access cable.{{cite web|last=Stark|first=Liz|title=Reading Between the LInes: Northern Stage|url=http://arts.gov/big-read/2011/reading-between-lines-northern-stage|publisher=National Endowment for the Arts|accessdate=23 December 2013|date=2011-04-15}} A major collaboration with [[Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center]] and [[Dartmouth Medical School]] to send students and medical residents to Northern Stage’s production of ''[[Wit]]''. Other major collaborations have involved Opera North, Pentangle Arts Council, The Haven, CATV-8 Community Access Television, the [[Center for Cartoon Studies]], [[Norwich University]], the Hartford Library, the Quechee Library, and many area non-profits. == Director and Producer == In her career, Ciardelli has directed over 60 productions in association with Northern Stage. (CT Valley Spectator, Aaron Nobel). As a director, she has been honored by the New England Theatre Conference’s Moss Hart Awards for Excellence in Theater three times. Ciardelli directed a staged reading of Arthur Miller’s then-unpublished ''[[Resurrection Blues]]'', with the playwright himself in residence; has directed [[Patrick Stewart]] and [[Lisa Harrow]] in ''[[Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf?]]'';{{cite news|last=Warner|first=David|title=Miller's Tale|url=http://www.7dvt.com/2004/millers-tale|accessdate=23 December 2013|newspaper=Seven Days|date=25 February 2004}} and worked with British playwright Sonja Linden on the American Premiere of ''The Strange Passenger''. Ciardelli has directed eight World Premieres, 11 regional premieres, and premiere performances in Europe and Africa, including productions of ''Wit'', ''[[The Beauty Queen of Leenane]]'', ''[[I Am My Own Wife]]'', ''[[Pride’s Crossing]]'', and ''[[No Orchids for Miss Blandish (play)|No Orchids for Miss Blandish]]'', as well as a number of large-scale musicals. She has worked with actors from [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]], [[London]]'s West End, and around the world, as well as touring, as co-director, with ''I Am My Own Wife'' to [[Harare]], [[Zimbabwe]] and [[Edinburgh]], [[Scotland]].{{cite news|last=Brown|first=Mark|title=Edinburgh Festival: Growing Up on the Road to War|url=http://www.onstagescotland.co.uk/iammyownwife.htm|accessdate=23 December 2013|newspaper=The Telegraph|date=22 August 2007}}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{cite web|title=Award-Winning Play Coming to Zim|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/200704190323.html|work=All-Africa.com|accessdate=23 December 2013}} In the summer of 2010, she co-directed a production of ''[[Macbeth]]'' with Castle Theatre Company, which toured England and the northeast U.S., including Off-West End and Off-Broadway performances. Ciardelli has adapted a number of classical pieces for the stage. In 2007 she was commissioned by [[Dartmouth College]] to adapt [[Ovid]]’s ''[[Metamorphoses]]''. Her play ''The O Myths'' was performed as the basis of an international exchange between actors from [[New York City]], [[Zimbabwe]], [[Mexico]], and [[Romania]]. (The Herald.){{cite news|last=Randall|first=Lucy|title=Festival Presents Adaptation of Metamorphoses|url=http://thedartmouth.com/2007/07/06/arts/festival-presents-adaptation-of-metamorphoses|accessdate=23 December 2013|newspaper=The Dartmouth|date=6 July 2007}} Ed Siegel of [[The Boston Globe]] said in his review that ''The Shrew Tamer'' "feels a little like listening to a symphony orchestra speed through an edited version of Mahler before going all-out in Mantovani".{{cite web|url=http://archive.boston.com/ae/theater_arts/articles/2004/10/20/shrew_pairing_is_too_tame/|title='Shrew' pairing is too tame|work=[[The Boston Globe]]|date=October 20, 2004|accessdate=August 24, 2016|author=Seigel, Ed}} Working with director [[Nicolas Kent]], then the Artistic Director of the [[Tricycle Theatre]] in [[London]], she produced the U.S. premiere of a new adaptation of [[Lee Blessing]]’s ''A Walk In The Woods'', performed for the first time with a male/female cast, at Northern Stage;{{cite web|title=Nicolas Kent To Direct ''A Walk in the Woods''|url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/vermont/article/Nicolas-Kent-To-Direct-A-WALK-IN-THE-WOODS-20111011#|work=Broadway World|accessdate=25 December 2013}} the production subsequently transferred to The Tricycle Theatre.{{cite web|title=A Walk in the Woods|url=http://www.tricycle.co.uk/home/about-the-tricycle-pages/about-us-tab-menu/archive/archived-theatre-production/a-walk-in-the-woods/|work=Tricycle Theatre|accessdate=25 December 2013}} Additional producing includes: ''The Art Of The Storyteller - An Evening with Jodi Picoult'', U.S. producer; ''Tom Crean – Antarctic Adventure'', (Irish Repertory, NYC; Sugan Theatre, Boston; Big Arts, Florida; Northern Stage; Vermont, on tour since 2005 in U.K., Europe and Australia);{{cite news|last=Blankenship|first=Mark|title=Review: 'Tom Crean, Antarctic Explorer'|url=https://variety.com/2007/legit/reviews/tom-crean-antarctic-explorer-1200557680/|accessdate=25 December 2013|newspaper=Variety|date=22 July 2007}} world premiere of A Christmas Carol – the musical written by Robert J. Cronin;{{cite web|url=http://www.thebestarts.com/bobbycronin/|work=The Best Arts|accessdate=25 December 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130125051505/http://www.thebestarts.com/bobbycronin/|archivedate=25 January 2013|df=}} Take Two, a new musical written by Brett Schrier and Catherine Doherty{{cite web|title=Backstage with ''Take Two''|url=http://www.vpr.net/news_detail/84912/backstage-take-two/|work=Vermont Public Radio|accessdate=25 December 2013}} Ciardelli has partnered with U.K. based Developing Artist ; site-specific London company Specifiq, and is working with VOICETheatre, New York City. She is a Visiting Fellow of University College, Durham University, Durham, England; a guest artist and lecturer at the Vienna International School; Chad’s College, Durham University, England; Harare International Festival of the Arts, Zimbabwe; Durham Drama Festival, England, the Elderhostel Program Tour to the Fringe Festival, Edinburgh, Scotland; Dartmouth College, State University of New York, Albany; NH; New England Theatre Conference, Boston, MA; Phi Beta Capa, Regional Conference, Northeast Region;{{cite web|title=Behind the Scenes: A Conversation on Vermont's Regional Theater|url=http://www.flynncenter.org/performances-events/event-details.html?perf_no=7450|work=Flynn Center for the Performing Arts|accessdate=25 December 2013}} Kendal at Hanover, NH; Adventures in Learning, NH; Keene State College, NH and a teaching artist for the Vermont Arts Council. At the end of 2012, with a modernized, Arabic-American-Muslim interpretation of Miller’s ''[[A View from the Bridge]]'' under development, Ciardelli left the Northern Stage company.{{cite news|title=Arab-Muslim Production of ''A View From the Bridge'' Gets Reading at the Public Theater|url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/off-broadway/article/Arab-Muslim-Production-of-A-VIEW-FROM-THE-BRIDGE-Gets-Reading-at-The-Public-Theater-20130113|accessdate=23 December 2013|newspaper=Broadway World|date=13 January 2013}} In March 2013, Ciardelli directed [[A.R. Gurney]]'s ''[[Black Tie]]'' at [[Vienna's English Theatre]]. As a producer, she works with the J.C. Manheimer Agency, is a consultant to Global Campuses Foundation and worked with New World Power as a producer of Special Events and trade shows. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{cite web|title=Athena Lecture Series|url=http://www.northernstage.org/index.php/education/lecture-series|work=Northern Stage|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131228095340/http://northernstage.org/index.php/education/lecture-series|archivedate=2013-12-28|df=}} *{{cite web|title=Vermont Arts Council Teaching Artists Roster|url=http://vermontartsdirectory.org/directory/listing.php?id=00401|work=Vermont Arts Council|accessdate=25 December 2013}}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} *{{cite web|title=Black Tie|url=http://www.englishtheatre.at/english/season-201213/black-tie/director.html|work=Vienna's English Theatre|accessdate=25 December 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20150112020816/http://www.englishtheatre.at/english/season-201213/black-tie/director.html|archivedate=12 January 2015|df=}} *{{cite web|title=Northern Stage Past & Future|url=http://www.northernstage.org/index.php/pastfuture/past-future|accessdate=22 December 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140118194538/http://www.northernstage.org/index.php/pastfuture/past-future|archivedate=18 January 2014|df=}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ciardelli, Brooke}} [[Category:Writers from Burlington, Vermont]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Manhattan]] [[Category:Sarah Lawrence College alumni]] [[Category:Television producers from New York City]] [[Category:Women television producers]] [[Category:Artists from Burlington, Vermont]]

{{other people||Herbert Bauer (disambiguation){{!}}Herbert Bauer}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2015}} {{eastern name order|Balázs Béla}} {{Expand Hungarian|Balázs Béla|date=May 2010}} [[File:Balázs Béla.jpg|thumb|right|Béla Balázs c. 1910s]]
'''Béla Balázs''' ({{IPA-hu|ˈbeːlɒ ˈbɒlaːʒ|lang}}; 4 August 1884, [[Szeged]] – 17 May 1949, [[Budapest]]), born '''Herbert Bauer''', was a Hungarian-[[History of the Jews in Hungary|Jewish]] [[film criticism|film critic]], [[aesthetics|aesthete]], writer and poet. He was a proponent of [[formalist film theory]].
==Career== Balázs was the son of German-born parents, adopting his ''nom de plume'' in newspaper articles written before his 1902 move to Budapest, where he studied Hungarian and German at the Eötvös Collegium.
Balázs was a moving force in the [[Sonntagskreis]] or Sunday Circle, the intellectual discussion group which he founded in the autumn of 1915 together with Lajos Fülep, [[Arnold Hauser]], [[György Lukács]] and [[Karl Mannheim|Károly (Karl) Mannheim]]. Meetings were held at his flat on Sunday afternoons; already in December 1915 Balázs wrote in his diary of the success of the group.<ref name=gluck>Mary Gluck (1985) [https://books.google.com/books?id=TUdmFkDoIGUC&pg=PA15 ''Georg Lukács and His Generation, 1900–1918'']. Cambridge, Massachusetts: Harvard University Press. {{ISBN|0674348664}}. pp. 14–16</ref>
He is perhaps best remembered as the librettist of ''[[Bluebeard's Castle]]'' which he originally wrote for his roommate [[Zoltán Kodály]], who in turn introduced him to the eventual composer of the opera, [[Béla Bartók]]. This collaboration continued with the scenario for the ballet ''[[The Wooden Prince]]''.
The collapse of the short-lived [[Hungarian Soviet Republic]] under [[Béla Kun]] in 1919 began a long period of exile in Vienna and Germany and, from 1933 until 1945, the Soviet Union.
In Vienna he became a prolific writer of film reviews. His first book on film, ''Der Sichtbare Mensch'' (''The Visible Man'') (1924), helped found the German "film as a language" theory, which also exerted an influence on [[Sergei Eisenstein]] and [[Vsevolod Pudovkin]]. A popular consultant, he wrote the screenplay for [[G. W. Pabst]]'s film of ''[[The Threepenny Opera (1931 film)|Die Dreigroschenoper]]'' (1931), which became the object of a scandal and lawsuit by [[Bertolt Brecht|Brecht]] (who admitted to not reading the script) during production.
Later, he co-wrote (with [[Carl Mayer]]) and helped [[Leni Riefenstahl]] direct the film ''[[Das Blaue Licht]]'' (1932).<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20140222011309/http://www.walter-riml.at/walter-riml.at/-_1931_The_blue_light_-.html 1931 „the blue light“]. walter-riml.at</ref> Riefenstahl later removed Balázs's and Mayer's names from the credits because they were Jewish.<ref>[http://www.uni-konstanz.de/FuF/Philo/LitWiss/MedienWiss/Forsch/Telaviv/Riefenstahl-englisch.html Hanno Loewy: "Balazs' and Leni Riefenstahl's The blue Light. A martyr's story"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040430052226/http://www.uni-konstanz.de/FuF/Philo/LitWiss/MedienWiss/Forsch/Telaviv/Riefenstahl-englisch.html |date=30 April 2004 }}. Uni-konstanz.de. Retrieved on 24 May 2015.</ref> One of his best known films is ''[[Somewhere in Europe (film)|Somewhere in Europe]]'' (''It Happened in Europe'', 1947), directed by [[Géza von Radványi]].
His last years were marked by petty vexations at home and ever increasing recognition in the German-speaking world. In 1949, he received the most distinguished prize in [[Hungary]], the [[Kossuth Prize]]. Also in 1949, he finished ''Theory of the Film'', published posthumously in English (London: Denis Dobson, 1952). In 1958, the Béla Balázs Prize was founded and named for him as an award to recognize achievements in [[cinematography]].
==Selected filmography== * ''[[Modern Marriages]]'' (1924) * ''[[Madame Wants No Children]]'' (1926) * ''[[The Girl with the Five Zeros]]'' (1927) * ''[[Grand Hotel (1927 film)|Grand Hotel]]'' (1927) * ''[[Doña Juana (film)|Doña Juana]]'' (1927) * ''[[Sunday of Life]]'' (1931)

The '''Cave of Euripides''' is a narrow cave, approximately 47 meters deep with ten small chambers, on a hillside overlooking the [[Saronic Gulf]] in the area of Peristeria on the south coast of [[Salamis Island]], [[Greece]]. Its name derives from its reputation since ancient times as the place where the playwright [[Euripides]] came to write his [[tragedy|tragedies]]. The ancient authors [[Philochorus]] and [[Satyrus the Peripatetic|Satyrus]] described Euripides as a misanthrope who avoided society by lurking in a cave. The second century Roman author [[Aulus Gellius]] claimed to have visited the "grim and gloomy cavern" during his visit to Athens (Attic Nights XV.20).
==Archaeology== In the 1990s, excavations were carried out under the direction of Yannos G. Lolos, Assistant Professor of Prehistoric Archaeology at the [[University of Ioannina]], [[Epirus (region)|Epirus]], in collaboration with the Department of [[Palaeoanthropology]] of the Greek Ministry of Culture.
Finds date from the late [[Neolithic]] onward. They include stone implements and arrowheads; [[Mycenaean Greece|Mycenaean]] burials; 5th century BC Attic [[Pottery of ancient Greece|black glaze pottery]]; Roman period coins and [[votive]] figurines; and jewellery from the Frankish period, generally suggesting its long-term use as a place of refuge and worship. The most notable discovery was a fragmentary black-glaze [[skyphos]] dating from the late 5th century BC, with the letters ΕΥΡΙΠΠ, clearly part of the name Euripides, carefully inscribed in letters of the [[Hellenistic]] or [[Ancient Rome|Roman]] period. Lolos interpreted the cup as a votive offering to Euripides, confirmation of the devotion his poetry inspired in later periods.
Lolos also uncovered the foundations of a small rural sanctuary about 70 meters southwest of the cave, on the trail from the shore. Based on a marble phallus and other finds, he interpreted it as a sanctuary of [[Dionysus]], the patron god of Greek theatre.
==Access== The cave, unsignposted, is located between the settlements of [[Salamis Island#Peristeria|Peristeria]] and Kolones, about 350 meters northwest of the north end of Euripides Street, up a clear footpath. There is a steel door.
==References== *[http://users.otenet.gr/~sofras/cave.html The Cave of Euripides on Salamis], 1996 expedition report, Yannos Lolos *[https://web.archive.org/web/20131010132015/http://www.akamas.gr/uni/exc/cave.html Ακάμας: Σπήλαιο Ευριπίδη], G. Lolas (in Greek). *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070927232550/http://www.greekembassy.org/Embassy/content/en/Article.aspx?office=1&folder=254&article=1453 Important Archaeological Sites, Aristotles' Lyceum And Cave Of Euripides, Found in Greece Archaeologists Say], Embassy of Greece, Washington, DC, 14 January 1997 *[https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F20913FD395C0C708DDDA80894DF494D81 Clay pot points to Cave of Euripides], ''New York Times'', January 13, 1997

{{Use South African English|date=March 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Debora Patta | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1964|7|13|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Southern Rhodesia]] | nationality = [[South Africa]]n | alma_mater = [[University of Cape Town]] | occupation = [[Broadcast journalism|Broadcast journalist]], [[television producer]], [[radio personality]] | years_active = 1990–present | spouse = Mweli Mzizi (1996–2002)
Lance Levitas (2003–2011) Andrew Levy ( 2012 - present) | children = 2 }} '''Debora Patta''' (born 1 September 1964){{cite web|title=Debora Patta|url=http://w11.zetaboards.com/White_House/profile/3599886/|publisher=The White House|accessdate=21 November 2013}} is a [[South African]] [[Broadcast journalism|broadcast journalist]] and [[television producer]] investigative journalist. She was born in [[Southern Rhodesia]] (now [[Zimbabwe]]) and has origins from [[Calabria]], [[Italy]].{{cite web|title=Premio globo tricolore|url=http://www.radioemiliaromagna.it/eventi/premio_globo_tricolore.aspx|date=25 September 2010|publisher=RadioEmiliaRomagna|quote=la giornalista investigativa più famosa in Sudafrica, di origine calabrese ma nata in Zimbabwe, Debora Patta|language=Italian|accessdate=2 March 2013}}{{cite web|last=McRae|first=Fiona|title='La vita' looks 'bella' for Debora Patta|url=http://www.mediaclubsouthafrica.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1999:patta-121010&catid=49:medianews&Itemid=113|date=12 October 2010|publisher=mediaclubsouthafrica.com|accessdate=2 March 2013}}{{cite news|last=Segar|first=Sue|title=Interview with Debora Patta: Not all Glamour|url=http://www.witness.co.za/index.php?showcontent&global%5B_id%5D=8363|accessdate=2 March 2013|newspaper=The Witness|date=30 May 2008}} Patta is the Africa correspondent for the American news program ''[[The CBS Evening News]]''.{{cite news|title=Debora Patta nominated for a news Emmy |url=http://www.channel24.co.za/TV/News/Debora-Patta-nominated-for-a-news-Emmy-20150731 |publisher=24.com |date=31 July 2015}} She has been with CBS since 2013, following her departure from the long running investigative and current affairs show, 3rd Degree with Debora Patta.{{cite news |url=http://www.channel24.co.za/News/Local/Debora-Patta-quits-3rd-Degree-20130507 |title=Debora Patta quits 3rd Degree |publisher=24.com |date=7 May 2013}} ==Early life== Patta was born in Southern Rhodesia (now Zimbabwe), where her [[Italian South African|Italian father]] had emigrated as a railway employee. Her father was from [[Rome]], Italy and she lived there for a while when she was young. Her Italian family is originally from [[Praia a Mare]] in Calabria. When her father died, Patta and her sister inherited a hotel in Rome and holiday apartments in the south of Italy. She considers Italy her second home and travels there regularly.{{cite news|last=Riccardo|first=Orizio|title=Italiana la principessa zulu|url=http://archiviostorico.corriere.it/1996/gennaio/08/Italiana_principessa_zulu_co_0_9601082664.shtml|language=Italian|quote=e' nata 31 anni fa nella Rhodesia, dove papa' era emigrato come impiegato delle ferrovie e aveva fatto carriera. Poi la separazione dei genitori, il trasferimento con la madre in Sudafrica, il ritorno del padre a Roma, la cittadinanza sudafricana|accessdate=3 March 2013|newspaper=[[Corriere della Sera]]|date=8 January 1996}}{{cite news|title='Is ek nog Debora Patta?'|url=http://www.dieburger.com/Rubrieke/Gasrubriekskrywers/Is-ek-nog-Debora-Patta-20091009|language=Afrikaans|quote=En nou, op 45, is dit tyd om minder baas en meer ma te wees.|accessdate=4 March 2013|newspaper=Die Burger|date=9 October 2009}} She moved to South Africa with her mother, a nurse and devout Catholic, and her sister in 1976 after her parents divorced. She attended [[Rustenburg School for Girls]] in the [[Rondebosch]] suburb of Cape Town, where she [[Matriculation in South Africa|matriculated]] in 1981. Patta studied at the [[University of Cape Town]] where she obtained a [[Bachelor of Social Sciences]] in 1984.{{cite news|last=Koekemoer|first=Hanlie|title=Party Time Review: Ms Debora Patta|url=http://durbs.kwazulunatal.com/number20/page22.html|accessdate=4 March 2013|newspaper=Durbs Magazine|date=August–September 2007}}{{cite news|last=Govender|first=Michelle|title=No Glass Ceiling: My Interview with Debora Patta of 3rd Degree|url=http://sweetdesignsmagazine.com/200910deborapatta.php|date=October 2009|newspaper=Sweet Designs Magazine|accessdate=4 March 2013}} She briefly taught aerobics while at university.{{cite web|last=Wiesner |first=André |title=Interviews: Debora Patta |url=http://andrewiesner.com/index_files/Page4069.htm |year=2001 |publisher=WorldOnline Tiscali |accessdate=3 March 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120107000304/http://andrewiesner.com/index_files/Page4069.htm |archivedate=7 January 2012 }} ==Career== After graduating from university, Patta worked as a political activist teaching literacy in [[Cape Town]]'s squatter camps until 1990, when she started working as a freelance [[journalist|reporter]] for the [[BBC]].{{cite web|title=2009 Vodacom Women in The Media Awards finalists announced|url=http://www.mediaupdate.co.za/Default.aspx?IDStory=16300|date=29 May 2009|publisher=mediaupdate.co.za|accessdate=5 March 2013}}{{cite web|title=Healthcare of the Future: The Good, the Bad & the Nano? Media Round Table – 9 February 2011 Speaker Information|url=http://www.saasta.ac.za/images/stories/Downloads/MRT/Compiled%20speaker%20bios.pdf|publisher=South African Agency for Science and Technology Advancement|quote=1990 marked her first foray into journalism working as a production assistant for the BBC.|accessdate=5 March 2013}} ===Radio=== Patta joined [[Radio 702]] in [[Johannesburg]] as a reporter in 1990 and worked her way up to news [[editing|editor]] in 1994 and special assignments editor in 1997. The first news story she worked on that was aired on Radio 702 was about the return of [[African National Congress|ANC]] leader [[Oliver Tambo]] from exile in December 1990. In 1997 and 1998, while working as news and special assignments editor for Radio 702 and its sister station [[Cape Talk]], she investigated and reported on the [[1986 Mozambican Tupolev Tu-134 crash|1986 plane crash]] in which [[Mozambique|Mozambican]] President [[Samora Machel]] was killed.{{cite news|last=Patta|first=Debora|title=How Samora Machel signed his own death warrant|url=http://www.mg.co.za/article/1998-07-10-how-samora-machel-signed-his-own-death|accessdate=3 March 2013|newspaper=Mail & Guardian|date=10 July 1998}} She received several threatening phone calls during the investigation.{{cite news|author=Pule wa Sekano|title=3rd Degree's Patta threatened|url=http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/3rd-Degrees-Patta-threatened-20030511|accessdate=6 March 2013|newspaper=City Press|date=11 May 2003}} In June 1998 she participated in a post-apartheid [[Truth and Reconciliation Commission (South Africa)|Truth and Reconciliation Commission]] special hearing, providing expert opinion and assisting with questioning regarding the [[South African Airways Flight 295|1987 Helderberg plane crash]] and the Machel plane crash.{{cite web|title=Truth and Reconciliation Commission Special Hearing in Camera: Helderberg Flight, Cape Town 1-3 June 1998|url=http://www.info.gov.za/view/DownloadFileAction?id=70332|publisher=info.gov.za|accessdate=5 March 2013}} She was later interviewed for a 2008 ''[[Mayday (Canadian TV series)|Mayday]]'' (''Air Crash Investigation'' or ''Air Emergency'') documentary on the Helderberg plane crash.{{cite web|title=Air Crash Investigation: Cargo Conspiracy|url=http://natgeotv.com/za/air-crash-investigation/videos/cargo-conspiracy|publisher=National Geographic Channel|accessdate=5 March 2013}} In October 2013, Patta returned to Radio 702 as a stand-in talk radio host.{{cite news|title=Patta is Redi’s first stand in|url=http://www.iol.co.za/tonight/tv-radio/patta-is-redi-s-first-stand-in-1.1587002#.Uo4sp9IwrIw|accessdate=21 November 2013|newspaper=Cape Argus|date=4 October 2013}} ===Television=== Patta has worked for [[e.tv]], the first privately owned free-to-air television station in South Africa, since its inception in 1998. She started as a senior [[correspondent]] in Johannesburg and was subsequently appointed chief [[News presenter#News anchors|anchor]] of e.tv news.{{cite news|last=Roos|first=Martjie|title=`Tien uit tien,' loof kykers e.tv se nuus|url=http://152.111.1.88/argief/berigte/beeld/1999/01/21/4/7.html|language=Afrikaans|accessdate=8 March 2013|newspaper=Beeld|date=21 January 1999}}{{cite news|last=Malan|first=Mariana|title=Debora Patta oor nuwe uitdagings|url=http://152.111.1.87/argief/berigte/dieburger/2005/08/19/NJ/2/nmpatta.html|language=Afrikaans|accessdate=8 March 2013|newspaper=Die Burger|date=19 August 2005}}{{cite web|title=The fearless Patta|url=http://www.screenafrica.com/download_files/latest_edition/pdfs/SCAF-Oct08(33-54)_Web.pdf|publisher=screenafrica.com|date=October 2008|accessdate=7 March 2013}} From 2000 to 2013 she was the executive producer and anchor of the weekly current affairs television programme ''3rd Degree'', a show conceptualized by her which focused on hard-hitting interviews.{{cite web|title=3rd Degree|url=http://www.tvsa.co.za/showinfo.asp?showid=514|publisher=TVSA|accessdate=3 March 2013}}{{cite news|last=Vos|first=Ugen|title=Patta focuses on '3rd Degree'|url=http://www.hci.co.za/media-broadcasting/patta-focuses-on-3rd-degree/|accessdate=4 March 2013|newspaper=The Citizen|date=1 October 2009}}{{cite web|title=Debora Patta quits 3rd Degree|url=http://www.channel24.co.za/News/Local/Debora-Patta-quits-3rd-Degree-20130507|publisher=News24|date=7 May 2013|accessdate=14 May 2013}} The final episode of ''3rd Degree'' aired on 14 May 2013.{{cite news|last=Ferreira|first=Thinus|title=Debora Patta says goodbye|url=http://www.channel24.co.za/TV/News/Debora-Patta-says-goodbye-20130515|accessdate=15 May 2013|newspaper=Channel24|date=15 May 2013}} She has reported on major international stories such as the [[September 11 attacks]] and the [[death of Princess Diana]] and has interviewed many notable individuals including [[Shimon Peres]], [[Oprah Winfrey]], [[Nelson Mandela]], [[Thabo Mbeki]], [[Jacob Zuma]], [[Cyril Ramaphosa]], [[Julius Malema]], [[Eugène Terre'Blanche]] and [[Robert McBride (police officer)|Robert McBride]]. She was appointed [[Editing#Executive editor|editor-in-chief]] of e.tv news in 2005.{{cite news|title=New editor-in-chief for e.tv|url=http://www.bizcommunity.com/Article/196/15/7388.html|accessdate=4 March 2013|newspaper=bizcommunity.com|date=7 August 2005}}{{cite news|title=Private sector: Media|url=http://mg.co.za/article/2007-08-01-private-sector-media|accessdate=4 March 2013|newspaper=Mail & Guardian|quote=She is editor-in-chief for both e.tv and e.24, the cable news channel which launched its 24-hour news station in June 2008.|date=7 August 2008}} In 2009 she resigned her position as editor-in-chief, "to follow her passion for journalism" and focus on 3rd Degree.{{cite news|title=Debora Patta resigns as e.tv head of news|url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/south-africa/debora-patta-resigns-as-e-tv-head-of-news-1.460199#.UTJNY6JTCz5|accessdate=2 March 2013|newspaper=IOL|date=1 October 2009}} She played a key role in the launch of South Africa's first 24-hour news channel [[eNCA|eNews Channel Africa]] (eNCA) by e.tv in 2008.{{cite news|title=Media maven scoops top award|url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/south-africa/media-maven-scoops-top-award-1.453477#.UTOw7qJTCz5|accessdate=3 March 2013|newspaper=IOL|date=31 July 2009}}{{cite news|author=Issa Sikiti da Silva|title=eNews 24-hour channel takes to the airwaves|url=http://www.bizcommunity.com/Article/196/66/25069.html|date=2 June 2008|publisher=bizcommunity.com|accessdate=4 March 2013}} In 2012 a puppet version of Patta voiced by Nikki Jackman was cast as co-host of the [[news satire|satirical television news programme]] ''[[ZANews]]''.{{cite news|title=Debora Patta puppet to join ZA News|url=http://www.citypress.co.za/entertainment/debora-patta-puppet-to-join-za-news-20120801-3/|accessdate=3 March 2013|newspaper=[[City Press (South Africa)|City Press]]|date=1 August 2012}}{{cite news|last=Tagg|first=Tashi|title=Behind the Debora Patta puppet on ZANews|url=http://www.channel24.co.za/TV/FeaturedArticle/Behind-the-Debora-Patta-puppet-on-ZANews-20120821|quote=They chose Debora because she's good TV.|accessdate=3 March 2013|newspaper=News24|date=21 August 2012}} On 7 May 2013, e.tv and eNCA announced that Debora Patta had resigned "to pursue other interests as a freelancer for international news companies".{{cite web|title=3rd Degree and Debora Patta take a break|url=http://www.enca.com/south-africa/3rd-degree-and-debora-patta-take-break|date=7 May 2013|publisher=eNCA|accessdate=7 May 2013}}{{cite news|last=Ferreira|first=Thinus|title=Debora Patta leaving e.tv; 3rd Degree abruptly ending; Debora Patta resigns to pursue freelance opportunities|url=http://teeveetee.blogspot.com/2013/05/breaking-debora-patta-leaving-etv-3rd.html|accessdate=7 May 2013|newspaper=TV with Thinus|date=7 May 2013}} Following her departure from [[e.tv]], she began working as a foreign correspondent for CBS News.{{cite news |title=CBS News women on the front line: Debora Patta and Sarah Carter |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/cbs-news-women-on-the-front-line-debora-patta-sarah-carter/ |publisher=CBS News |date=5 March 2015}} ==Reporting style== Patta has been described as "arrogant", "insensitive", "aggressive" and "ruthless":{{cite news|last=Gophe|first=Myolisi|title=Rape group protests over Patta's patter|url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/south-africa/rape-group-protests-over-patta-s-patter-1.122545#.UTS7eqJTCz5|accessdate=4 March 2013|newspaper=IOL|date=3 February 2004}}{{cite news|author=Issa Sikiti da Silva|title=Programme praised, Patta panned|url=http://www.bizcommunity.com/Article/196/66/38100.html|accessdate=5 March 2013|newspaper=bizcommunity.com|date=21 July 2009}} {{blockquote|South Africans know her best as the hard-core investigative reporter who ruthlessly rips into everyone from crooked cabinet ministers to medical doctors on the take.|Louise Liebenberg|''The Herald''{{cite news|last=Liebenberg |first=Louise |title=Sad stories make tough journo Debora cry |url=http://www.theherald.co.za/femme/2003/09/17/issues.htm |quote=Debora, 'a very proud South African' |accessdate=3 March 2013 |newspaper=The Herald |date=17 September 2003 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070402215004/http://www.theherald.co.za/femme/2003/09/17/issues.htm |archivedate=2 April 2007 }}}} {{blockquote|Patta has been called names and is often described as aggressive, but it doesn't seem to bother her much.|Bongiwe Khumalo|''Times Live''{{cite news|last=Khumalo|first=Bongiwe|title=Nothing 'pitter' about Patta|url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/entertainment/article467597.ece/Nothing-pitter-about-Patta|accessdate=3 March 2013|newspaper=Times Live|date=24 May 2010}}}} Her hard-hitting journalism exposing racism in South Africa has angered conservative [[White South African|whites]]. [[Black people#Republic of South Africa|Black]] members of the public have also accused her of being [[Racism|racist]], e.g. after exposing corrupt black doctors who sold medical certificates and after interviewing "[[Bling-bling|bling]] queen" [[Khanyi Mbau]], and [[Jews|Jewish]] members of the public have accused her of being [[Antisemitism|anti-Semitic]] after airing the controversial 2002 documentary ''[[Palestine Is Still the Issue]]''.{{cite news|last=Hoffman|first=Gerjo|title=Patta says it doesn't matta|url=http://www.news24.com/Entertainment/SouthAfrica/Patta-says-it-doesnt-matta-20030511|accessdate=16 March 2013|newspaper=Die Burger|date=11 May 2003}}{{cite news|last=Tabane|first=Rapule|title=An embarrassment of riches|url=http://mg.co.za/article/2010-12-23-an-embarrassment-of-riches|accessdate=15 March 2013|newspaper=Mail & Guardian|date=23 Dec 2010}}{{cite news|last=Masithela|first=Tsietsi|title=Debora Patta is no racist|url=http://152.111.1.87/argief/berigte/dailysun/2010/12/17/DJ/47/letter1.html|accessdate=15 March 2013|newspaper=Daily Sun|date=17 December 2010}} She has also been criticized as not being qualified to talk about black culture by former [[African National Congress Youth League|ANC Youth League]] president [[Julius Malema]] during an interview with him and by black viewers offended by a ''3rd Degree'' show on black [[Artificial hair integrations|hair weaves]].{{cite news|author=Issa Sikiti da Silva|title=3rd Degree: a decade of ‘blood-on-the-floor' journalism|url=http://www.bizcommunity.com/Article/196/66/47607.html|accessdate=6 March 2013|newspaper=bizcommunity.com|date=11 May 2010}}{{cite news|last=Lewis|first=Esther|title=3rd degree makes waves over weaves|url=http://www.iol.co.za/lifestyle/style/beauty/3rd-degree-makes-waves-over-weaves-1.1330618#.UTb9PtZTCz4|accessdate=6 March 2013|newspaper=Cape Argus|date=29 June 2012}} [[Afrikaner Weerstandsbeweging|AWB]] leader [[Eugène Terre'Blanche]] walked out of an interview with Patta after his release from prison in 2004. A complaint lodged against e.tv about the interview was dismissed by the [[Broadcasting Complaints Commission of South Africa]].{{cite web|title=Case No - 28-2004 - e.tv - 3rd Degree - Eugene Terrblanche - Comment|url=http://www.bccsa.co.za/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=233:case-no-28-2004-comment&catid=13&Itemid=2|publisher=BCCSA|accessdate=5 March 2013}} In 2010 Patta publicly apologized on television to Chrisna de Kock, a [[Freedom Front Plus]] youth leader at the [[University of the Free State]], after accusing her of being a racist in an interview on ''3rd Degree''. An e.tv spokesperson conceded that "the manner in which the allegation was put across was unfortunate" and the racism comment was subsequently retracted.{{cite news|title=Debora Patta to apologise to FF Plus leader|url=http://mg.co.za/article/2010-07-06-debora-patta-to-apologise-ff-plus-leader|accessdate=4 March 2013|newspaper=Mail & Guardian|date=6 July 2010}}{{cite news|last=du Toit|first=Pieter|title=Debora Patta says sorry|url=http://www.news24.com/SouthAfrica/News/Debora-Patta-says-sorry-20100708|accessdate=3 March 2013|newspaper=Beeld|date=8 July 2010}} Patta has responded to criticism of her reporting with statements such as "that means I am doing my job well" and "we are doing this because we have a true democracy". ==Personal life== In April 1995 Patta, a white woman, announced over the radio her plans to marry Mweli Mzizi, a black filmmaker and [[Zulu people|Zulu]] prince. The interracial couple had encountered hostility for a year, so she was surprised by the positive response of listeners to her announcement.{{cite web|last=Matloff|first=Judith|title=Life in the New South Africa: Racial Strife Slowly Easing|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/1995/0427/27051.html|date=27 April 1995|publisher=The Christian Science Monitor|accessdate=2 March 2013}} They were married in January 1996 and the wedding was attended by hundreds of guests including Nelson Mandela. After the wedding the [[Department of Home Affairs (South Africa)|Department of Home Affairs]] notified Mzizi that the marriage was invalid because he did not fill out a form requiring black men to say that they were not already married. ''[[Newsweek]]'' reported that few South Africans were aware of this requirement and "many of the country's marriages are probably illegal in the eyes of the bureaucracy".{{cite news|title=So You Think You're Married?|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/newsweek/1996/04/07/so-you-think-you-re-married.html|accessdate=3 March 2013|newspaper=[[Newsweek]]|date=7 April 1996}} In 2000 Patta and Mzizi unsuccessfully attempted to enter a whites-only picnic resort in the [[Free State (province)|Free State]] together, filming the incident on a hidden camera for a ''3rd Degree'' show on racism following which Patta received hate mail.{{cite news|last=Scott|first=Sally|title=Racist resort gets the 3rd Degree|url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/south-africa/racist-resort-gets-the-3rd-degree-1.52676#.UTN7gaJTCz4|accessdate=3 March 2013|newspaper=IOL|date=9 November 2000}} In April 2002 it was reported that Patta and Mzizi were divorcing.{{cite news|title=Mzizi and Patta's break-up tears family apart|url=http://152.111.1.87/argief/berigte/citypress/2002/04/28/4/14.html|accessdate=2 March 2013|newspaper=[[City Press (South Africa)|City Press]]|date=28 April 2002}} Patta was voted one of the ''FHM 50 Most Eligible Women in the World'' by South African ''[[FHM]]'' readers in 2003.{{cite news|last=Nel|first=Jaco|title=Debora Patta: Sonder skroom|url=http://www.beeld.com/XArchive/Plus/Debora-PattaSonder-skroom-20100617|accessdate=5 March 2013|quote=Sy het aan die begin van die jaar die tydskrif FHM se lysie gehaal van die mees hubare vroue in die land.|language=Afrikaans|newspaper=Beeld|date=21 May 2003}}{{cite news|title=Hubaarste vroue|url=http://152.111.1.88/argief/berigte/beeld/2003/01/09/1/2.html|date=9 Jan 2003|quote=Van die kriteria is dat hulle geld en bekende vriende moet hê en intelligent moet wees.|language=Afrikaans|publisher=Beeld|accessdate=5 March 2013}} In June 2003 she married businessman Lance Levitas.{{cite web|title=Newsletter Number 49 |url=http://www.rgjs.co.za/ROGU/Newsletters/49.pdf|date=December 2008|publisher=RGJS|accessdate=3 March 2013}}{{cite news|title=Debora Patta ties the knot|url=http://www.news24.com/Entertainment/SouthAfrica/Debora-Patta-ties-the-knot-20030717|accessdate=2 March 2013|newspaper=News24|date=17 July 2003}} She has two daughters, one from each marriage. Her elder daughter Chiara Mzizi has worked as a presenter for YoTV, a youth entertainment show broadcast by [[SABC 1]].{{cite web|title=Girls|url=http://www.starqualitymanagement.net/girls.php|publisher=SQ Artiste Management and Acting Academy|accessdate=4 March 2013}} Levitas divorced Patta in 2015 and remarried in 2017. When approached for comment as to why he sued for divorce Levitas remarked, "now is not the time to comment" ==Awards== Patta has won several awards: * 1992 South African Checkers Journalist of the Year * 2004 [[Vodacom Journalist of the Year Awards|Vodacom Journalist of the Year]] Gauteng Region * 2004 MTN 10 Most Remarkable Women in Media * 2007 Simonsvlei Journalist Achiever of the Year{{cite |publisher=Elle South Africa |date=3 August 2015}} ==Publications== * ''Baby Micaela : the inside story of South Africa's most famous abduction case''. The '''Triennial E. A. Lowe Lectures''' are an ongoing series of lectures held at [[Corpus Christi College, Oxford|Corpus Christi College]], [[University of Oxford]], in memory of the noted palaeographer [[Elias Avery Lowe|E. A. Lowe]] who was an [[Honorary title (academic)|Honorary Fellow]] of the College from 1954 until his death in 1969. They are delivered by prominent [[Palaeography|palaeographers]], with each scholar giving a trio of lectures on a topic within the field.<ref name=Jonge>{{cite web |title=Erik Kwakkel Becomes 2014 E.A. Lowe Lecturer in Oxford |publisher=De Jonge Akademie |date=5 Nov 2012 |accessdate=23 Jan 2017 |url=https://www.dejongeakademie.nl/en/nieuws/erik-kwakkel-e-a-lowe-lecturer-oxford}}</ref> Oxford University Press sometimes publishes revised versions of the lectures. Lecturers have included N. G. Wilson, [[A. C. de la Mare]], Anthony Grafton, and Michael Lapidge.<ref name=CCCLect>{{cite web |title=Special Lectures |publisher=Corpus Christi College, Oxford University |date=2016 |accessdate=23 Jan 2017 |url=https://www.ccc.ox.ac.uk/Special-Lectures/}}</ref><ref name=Leiden>{{cite web |title=Erik Kwakkel to hold the 2014 E. A. Lowe Lectures in Corpus Christi College, Oxford |publisher=Turning Over a New Leaf, Universiteit Leiden |date=17 Jan 2014 |accessdate=23 Jan 2017 |url=http://www.hum.leiden.edu/lucas/turning-over-a-new-leaf/news/lowelectures.html}}</ref>
==Lectures== * 2017 — Rodney Thomson: ''The Fox and the Bees: the First Century of the Library of Corpus Christi College'' ** Lecture 1 (22 Feb 2017): The Founder as Shaping Force: [[Richard Foxe|Richard Fox]] and his Books ** Lecture 2 (24 Feb 2017): The First President as Fox’s Instrument: [[John Claymond]]’s Donations ** Lecture 3 (27 Feb 2017): The Library They Produced<ref name=CCCLowe>{{cite web |title=E. A. Lowe Lectures in Palaeography 2017 |publisher=Corpus Christi College, Oxford University |date=2016 |accessdate=23 Jan 2017 |url=http://www.ccc.ox.ac.uk/E.-A.-Lowe-Lectures-in-Palaeography-2011/}}</ref> * 2014 — [[Erik Kwakkel]]: ''The Birth of Gothic Script'' ** Lecture 1 (21 Feb 2014): The Evolution from [[Carolingian minuscule|Caroline Minuscule]] to Gothic Textualis ** Lecture 2 (25 Feb 2014): Regional Variety ** Lecture 3 (27 Feb 2014): Adopting a New Script<ref name=Leiden/> * 2011 — David Ganz: ''Latin Manuscript Books Prior to the Ninth Century: Ways of Using [[Codices Latini Antiquiores]]'' ** Lecture 1 (9 May 2011): Evaluating the Evidence ** Lecture 2 (16 May 2011): Scribes and their Patrons ** Lecture 3 (23 May 2011): [[Uncial script#Half-uncial|Half-Uncial Scripts]]<ref name=Gazette11>{{cite news |title=Lectures and Seminars, Trinity Term 2011 |work=Gazette Supplement |publisher=Oxford University |page=555 |date=27 Apr 2011 |accessdate=23 Jan 2017 |url=http://www.ox.ac.uk/media/global/wwwoxacuk/localsites/gazette/documents/supplements2010-11/Lectures_and_Seminars,_Trinity_term_2011_(1)_to_No._4949.pdf}}</ref> * 2008 — Susan Rankin: ''Impressed on the Memory: Musical Sounds and Notations in the Ninth Century'' ** Lecture 1 (26 Feb 2008): Case Study One: The [[Abbey of St Gall]] ** Lecture 2 (28 Feb 2008): Case Study Two: The [[Laon Cathedral|Cathedral of Laon]] ** Lecture 3 (6 Mar 2008): Musical Notation as a [[Carolingian Renaissance|Carolingian Phenomenon]]<ref name=Gazette08>{{cite news |title=Lectures |work=Gazette |publisher=Oxford University |date=21 Feb 2008 |accessdate=23 Jan 2017 |url=http://www.ox.ac.uk/gazette/2007-8/weekly/210208/lecs.htm#19Ref}}</ref> * 2005 — Virginia Brown: ''[[Beneventan Script]] and the Culture of Medieval Southern Italy'' ** Lecture 1 (22 Feb 2005): [[Elias Avery Lowe|E.A. Lowe]] and the Making of ''The Beneventan Script'' ** Lecture 2 (24 Feb 2005): In the Shadow of [[Monte Cassino|Montecassino]]: Beneventan Writing Centres in the [[Abruzzo|Abruzzi]] ** Lecture 3 (1 Mar 2005): Across the Adriatic: Beneventan Scriptoria in [[Dalmatia]]<ref name=Gazette05>{{cite news |title=Lectures |work=Gazette |publisher=Oxford University |date=3 Feb 2005 |accessdate=23 Jan 2017 |url=http://www.ox.ac.uk/gazette/2004-5/weekly/030205/lecs.htm#23Ref}}</ref> * 2002 — [[Michael Lapidge]]: ''The [[Anglo-Saxons|Anglo-Saxon]] Library'' ** Lecture 1 (24 Jan 2002): Vanished Libraries ** Lecture 2 (31 Jan 2002): Reconstructing Anglo-Saxon Libraries: The Evidence of Manuscripts ** Lecture 3 (7 Feb 2002): Reconstructing Anglo-Saxon Libraries: The Evidence of Citations<ref name=Gazette02>{{cite news |title=Lectures |work=Gazette |publisher=Oxford University |date=10 Jan 2002 |accessdate=23 Jan 2017 |url=http://www.ox.ac.uk/gazette/2001-2/weekly/100102/lecs.htm#28Ref}}</ref> * 1999 — Michael Reeve: ''Manuscripts and Method: The Transmission of [[Publius Flavius Vegetius Renatus|Vegetius]]'' ** Lecture 1 (25 Jan 1999): A Proposal about [[Modestus (Apostle of Carantania)|Modestus]] ** Lecture 2 (1 Feb 1999): A Man on a Horse ** Lecture 3 (8 Feb 1999): R.<ref name=Gazette99>{{cite news |title=Lectures |work=Gazette |publisher=Oxford University |date=14 Jan 1999 |accessdate=23 Jan 2017 |url=http://www.ox.ac.uk/gazette/1998-9/weekly/140199/lecs.htm#56Ref}}</ref> * 1996 — [[Anthony Grafton]]: ''Ancient History in Early Modern Europe'' ** Lecture 1 (24 Jan 1996): The Reading and Teaching of the Ancient Historians ** Lecture 2 (26 Jan 1996): The Antiquarians and the Reconstruction of Ancient Societies ** Lecture 3 (29 Jan 1996): The Rediscovery of Barbarian Texts and Civilisations<ref name=Gazette96>{{cite news |title=Lectures |work=Gazette |publisher=Oxford University |date=5
